review: Hard hitting drama with incredibly touching performances, something quite rare this day and age. A real master stroke was to focus on the awakening of a boy as he senses and suffers existence; it makes you feel part of his progression and realizations, as he initially enters the world with his mind prone to fantasy and un aware of inhumanity.

It's hard to think of a more emotionally grueling and uplifting movie this year than Room. It drops you right into a scary world and, thanks to its carefully balanced tone, the film eschews sensationalism and gets at the beating heart of its survival story, namely the love and protection of a mother for her son. It is an emotionally powerful story that hits the big moments, the small moments, and everything in between. It left me analyzing it and rethinking it for hours, the repercussions still reverberating through me. Ma (Brie Larson) has been held in a single soundproof room for seven years, the captive of an older man who is termed "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers). Complicating matters is that Ma has a five-year-old son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) born into this captivity. It is the only world he's known. To spare him the full horror of their circumstances, Ma has created an elaborate world for him that only exists in Room. After his fifth birthday, Ma tries speaking honestly to her son, lifting the veil of kind fabrications. Together they will scheme to escape their one-room world, but it comes with tremendous cost. It would be easy to fall onto the more seemly elements of this harrowing story and linger on just how bad things are and the horrifying lengths that Ma has to go through to survive. Director Lenny Abrahamson (Frank) doesn't have to wallow in depravity to get its point across. There's a sensitivity that manages to temper some of the abuse in a manner that won't make you run out of the room screaming. When Old Nick enters the room for his special time with Ma, we don't need explicit detail to understand what is happening and what Ma is shielding Jack from by demanding he stay in the closet. The reality of their captivity is enough without underlining the worst of the worst for the lowest common denominator. The emotional weight of everything is clear without having to be bludgeoned. The implications are always just peaking around the corners from the safer version of reality Ma has proposed to protect her child. As the audience, we can see the cracks, we can see her front, and we can see the effort and the toll it's taking on Ma. The stakes are clear as well, and so when Ma is instructing Jack and preparing him on their joint escape plan, you'll start to feel waves of anxiety travel through your body. I was shaking with suspense that something could go wrong but also because Ma and Jack are such vulnerable characters that rely upon one another completely. I knew what was going to happen in broad strokes but I was still on the edge of my seat and that's because the movie made me deeply care about the characters and their plight. The escape scene was on par with some of the better suspense sequences in the equally brilliant Sicario. It's not really a spoiler to say that Ma and Jack do get out of their one-room prison because the second half of the film deals with the ongoing consequences and challenges of adjustment. We'd like to think that we can be plugged into our old lives after spending time away, but that's just not how things work, let alone for people who have experienced substantial psychological and physical trauma. Ma is struggling to readjust to her old life under the care of her mother, Nancy (Joan Allen). She looks through old high school pictures and you can tell she laments "what could have been" and even bears some resentment for her old friends who got to live the lives she should have had. Just because she's free doesn't mean she's better. Her father Robert (William H. Macy), since divorced from Ma's mother, can't even look at Jack because of the pain it causes; Jack is a child of rape, but Ma demands he be acknowledged as her flesh-and-blood, and even that can be too much too soon for Robert. He's more about seeking justice through the courts and as a result stays on the peripheral of the story for most of the movie. There is no exact time table for PTSD and Ma goes through highs and lows, none lower than when pressed with the question of why she held onto Jack after he was born. Would he not have had a better life in someone else's care, assuming Old Nick would have abandoned him rather than kill his own blood? It's a hard question and it stings. For an obviously punishing story about the worst of humanity, I am not kidding when I say Room is an uplifting film. The darkness is easy to identify and Old Nick is a fearsome and all too real antagonist, one who could roam our very streets in anonymity. However, what stays with me several days after watching Room is not the suffering but the resiliency of spirit, the knack human beings have to persevere amidst the worst. Ma's recovery is rockier but more understandable for us to trace and relate with. Hers is an experience where she can finally begin to focus on something other than her child's safety and deliverance, namely her own well-being. For Jack, there is no playbook. He's spent his entire life inside a small room and never seen the outside world. His sense of understanding has been extremely limited and yet his sense of exploration is alive. Jack slowly and surely builds trusting relationships with Ma's relatives, engaging in other activities, and acclimating to his new surroundings, reforming his sense of the world. It's ultimately Jack who is able to make the greatest breakthrough to his mother, and it's this moment of sacrifice and love that unleashed the last torrent of my tears. Previously I had cried two times over the horrors and Ma's love as her strength, and it was this final moment, this sharing of his "Strong," that let loose the happy tears. It should go without saying but Larson gives an exceptionally powerful performance. After 2013's stupendous Short Term 12, I knew this actress was destined for great things, especially the way she can zero in on a character and inhabit them fully. With Ma (she's never given any other name) Larson is able to convey a multitude of emotions, many of which she has to hide from her son out of loving deference. He can't know just how scared and exhausted she is, though these emotions do take over at time. Larson is tremendous as she exhumes maternal might as she does everything in her power to save the two of them. Early on, she's the character we empathize with the most because she's had her world taken from her and hoping to return. She's so resourceful, from the way she's able to answer her son's questions about the world, to the way she's able to practice and drill their escape plan to a child with no concept of "outside," this is a powerful woman driven by the instinct to endure. When Larson's fa�ade breaks down with Jack, that's when the movie started stabbing me like daggers. In the second half, her character has a long road to go to recovery, if that's even an appropriate word, and Larson gives sensitive and empathetic consideration to every exhausted development. She is easily going to be the one to beat this year for the Best Actress Oscar.Paired with Larson is the remarkably natural child actor Jacob Tremblay, and his performance is worthy of awards consideration itself. At first his worldview is precocious because of how unique it is, which makes him more a figure of fascination than tragedy. He's bright and active with the world around him, turning household items into useful toys and emotional attachments. The film uses parts of his narration to give better insight into just how he's processing the world he knows versus the world as it exists. These bouts of narration never come across as cloying. As the movie continues, he learns more about how his preconceptions of the world are wrong, but he's more intrigued than frightened. During the escape plan, when Jack gets to see the outside world for the first time, it's a transcendent emotional moment. His guarded behavior around others is necessary as Jack builds positive associations with men who are not Old Nick. Tremblay is utterly magnificent; there is no hint of artifice to his performance, which is especially rewarding considering his is a role that could have been suffocated with eccentricities and tics. You feel like you're watching a child grow before you through supportive nurturing. Within the first twenty minutes of watching Room I already knew this was one of the best films of 2015. It just connects so vividly and succinctly, effortlessly powerful and yet skillfully avoiding sensationalism and exploitation while telling an entertaining survival story that still resonates with emotional truth. The performances from mother and son are outstanding and Larson and Tremblay form a heroic duo that take hold of your heart. It doesn't mitigate the darkness or the cruel realities of its premise but Room also doesn't dwell in the darkness, castigating its characters as hapless victims forever broken from their incalculable suffering. They are resourceful and resilient and while their trauma is will not be forgotten it is not the one defining moment of their burgeoning lives. It may sound maudlin but it is the power of love that resonates the longest with Room. That love at first is about protecting the innocent, and then it transforms into healing and acceptance. I hope everybody gets a chance to see Room, a remarkable film with two remarkable performances and plenty to say about the humanizing benefit of love. Nate's Grade: A

Simple yet profound, small yet grande, "Room" is one of the most complex and thought-provoking films I have seen in a very long time. Maybe not complex to everyone, if you look at the imagery, camerawork, and script choices, there really is something incredible here. After being raised in a room for five years, with no outdoor contact, Jack and his Ma Joy escape and see daylight for the first in a long time. Told through the perspective of the child, he is seeing the world, people, objects, and nature, all for the first time. The emotional impact that has on the story is breathtaking. Brie Larson gives a gut-wrenching performance and I believed every single scene she was in. Starting from a confined room, you really begin to see what the world is truly like and how we take everything for granted that is in it. I loved "Room" from start to finish. Although I believe this is a brilliant film overall, I have to complain about the way they were able to escape. It felt a little too easy and then that tension was gone throughout the rest of the film in order to focus on the emotional heft, i.e. the family. In the end, "Room" has a very raw and true screenplay, incredible performances, inspiring visuals, and a story that is once in a generation, and we do not get many of those. I wish it did not have an easy way out in the opening act, but overall, I feel I can still give it a perfect score. See this film!

Room is a masterwork that tells a story of captivity and the wonders of the real world. Its a very sad story, but also a hopeful one. Brie Larson gives one of the best performances I have seen in quite a long time. She is a revelation. Her dark, truthful, scared and emotional performance is something truly fascinating. She puts her soul into this character, and it pays off in spades. A few months ago I honestly didn't know much of her, but now I see her as one of the most promising new actresses in the business. Jacob Tremblay further proves my belief that child actors can truly make our jaws drop. Tremblay deserves all the praise in the world for his heartwarming and complex performance, completely capturing the mindset of a young boy being introduced to the world for the first time. Its something truly spectacular, and I kept going back and forth trying to decide if he or Larson stole the show. They both really worked perfectly together. Joan Allen is another underrated performance, as she gives a sweet and loving performance as the grandmother. Her giving a brilliant performance as a mother who lost her daughter and attempts to have a relationship with her grandson is heartwarming. The script from Emma Donoghue is something truly spectacular. She gives us a terrifying real look into the minds of these characters and bringing life to their situation. There was a moment halfway through the film that had me in tears and cheering. Its amazing that a fictional story could feel so much like a true story. Director Lenny Abrahamson

STUCK HOME SYNDROME - My Review of ROOM (4 Stars)Don't let the bright wonderment of the poster fool you, ROOM is one of the most emotionally devastating films of the year, anchored by beyond stellar performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, a young Canadian actor whose focus and range rivals that of Tatum O'Neal in PAPER MOON. Prepare to be gutted. It's almost impossible to describe this film without spoilers, but I'll do just that. If you've read Emma Donoghue's novel, of which she adapted for the screen, then you already know the basic premise of a mother (Larson) raising her 5-year-old son, Jack (Tremblay) in a tiny room. Shielding him from the world for reasons that become clear upon viewing, he doesn't know that any type of life exists beyond his four walls. Think of this as a much more emotionally vibrant and more honest sister film to LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL, which also explored the lengths a parent will go to in order to protect their child. Much of the first half of this film is fraught with unbearable suspense, with the mother doing everything she can to resolve their situation. Danny King, whose work on LES MISERABLES did not make me a fan, employs a live camera and a lot of shallow focus to put the point of view squarely on the shoulders of our two protagonists. Yes, it's a claustrophobic experience, but to feel otherwise would be doing the subject matter a disservice. Director Lenny Abrahamson has made an intimate film about big ideas, and there's very smart economy in its storytelling. It's overlong by at least 20-30 minutes, however, and with such a generous running time of almost two hours, you would expect a little more to William H. Macy's lightly sketched in, barely there character. It's not that he's incapable, but he's given way too little to work with here. Not so of Joan Allen, who digs deep with limited screen time as well. Also tremendously effective in supporting roles are Sean Bridgers, who has a knack for keeping an audience on edge, Wendy Crewson as a journalist who prods just a little bit too much, and Amanda Brugel, as a woman who has to assert herself in order to cut through the muck. I could have done without the tin can-style of recording the voiceover, which certainly feels unsettling, but was truly difficult to comprehend at times. The score by Stephen Rennicks is certainly beautiful and heartfelt, but he could have dialed it back a hair with the final music cue. There was so much sap in it, I was tempted to call the film MUSHROOM! Far from it, this is a challenging experience, often seen through tears, and not an easy sit for any parent who worries about their child. Larson and Tremblay should be firmly in the mix come Awards season. Larson continually surprises me with her performances. Looking like Reese Witherspoon's sister, I keep expecting her to act goofy and self-conscious, yet her instincts are so vibrantly attuned to the material, she seems incapable of making a false move. Whether he has natural abilities or was heavily directed, Tremblay is a highly sympathetic actor whose ability to annoy, infuriate and warm an audience's heart, sometimes within the same scene, is something special to behold. ROOM is very dark, sad, and sometimes without a shred of hope, yet this tale of a Herculean bond between mother and son is well worth all the sobbing you'll likely find yourself doing afterwards.

Room's wonderful performances and excellent direction are backed by a screenplay that's filled with subtlety, intelligence, and heart. Though Room has a few minor errors, such as a final act that feels like it could have benefitted from an additional scene or two of development, there are very few films that have had me as emotionally invested in a story as Room, making it one of the best movies of the year. And if that isn't enough, one sequence in the film had me on the edge of my seat more than any sequence in a film this year.

Based on a bestselling Emma Donnaghue novel, Room (not to be confused with the cult B-movie THE Room) tells the morbid story of a young woman who was kidnapped, held inside a small, soundproof dungeon of a room, raped, and gave birth to her captor's child. The film opens up in medias res with this young mother in her seventh year of captivity, trying to survive in squalid conditions with her young son and teach him about a world he has never seen. The first act shows some of the most claustrophobic and focused filmmaking this year. We are stuck with these characters in this doomed situation, with only hints of the outside world. Brie Larson impresses us as the young woman who was denied years of her life and we see how her imprisonment and its aftermath have worn on her. Jacob Tremblay also deserves some recognition for convincingly playing a boy who has never traveled more than five feet from where he was born and never met a person other than his mother. Room loses steam toward the end and fails to recapture the engrossing magic that had us at the edge of our seat for the first 35 minutes, but it still has a simple and definitive end that most awards season fare denies the audience. A must see.

Room is an immensely engaging and beautifully performed film. Intriguing and thought-provoking. The main action in the plot is perhaps zipped through too quickly for all the eventual payoffs to be truly satisfying, but there's no denying the care that has been taken in delivering a respectful adaptation. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are absolutely lovely together. Rating: 84

The performances are quite good and it's hard to deny the power of certain moments . . . however this story was begging for a more stylistically ambitious film than the one we got. As it stands, "Room" seems like something made for television.
An emotionally exhausting, perfectly acted film about the love between a mother and a child.

At its heart Room is a psychological thriller showing the true essence of the mother-child relationship. Terrific acting by all notably Larson and Tremblay. both who are worthy of Oscar nominations. Definitely one of the top movies that I have seen this year. (12-23-15)
A unique film in that it starts off very suspenseful, and ends very quietly... but in a good way. Jacob Tremblay does an amazing job, and Brie Larson delivers a strong performance as well.
While there is no denying that Room was superb, and despite the fact that I'm usually drawn to simple yet well-made films, I wasn't quite captivated.

Room is spectacular. Ok, well, half spectacular. The first half admittedly flies by but it's such an interesting premise helmed by two excellent performances from the get-go. It's a movie I'd give an A+ up until the 1:10 mark (or so) but afterwards it starts a steady decline of mundaneness. It could have really benefited from a stretched out first half with more thrills OR maybe Terrence Malick assisting the second to try to actually capture the wonder of the world. Instead it's just a bumpy finish to an otherwise incredible race.

'Room' is profoundly moving - it transforms what is essentially a terrifying situation into a fairy tale about the love between a mother and her child. The kid, Jacob Tremblay, is a revelation... and Brie Larson is outstanding as well.

I was beginning to lose faith in the Academy's selection capability considering I've only really liked 2 of the Best Pic nominees so far, or consider them worthy. "Room" is a traditional Academy darling, and rightfully so. It's dramatic, emotional, suspenseful and a phenomenal film. The story is intense and heartbreaking (times 4 or 5). The acting performances of Brie Larson and young Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscar recognition. While I haven't seen all the performances nominated thus far, young Jacob Tremblay is jaw-dropping. I was excited to see Brie Larson, one of my favorites, finally show her stuff, and that she did. I hope she gets the win. However, Jacob blew me away. There were no words to describe how incredible his performance is for someone so young. Better than any adult actor I've seen this year. I'm serious. There is an incredible career in the making there. The screenplay, based on the novel of the same name, is beautiful. Aside from one scene that bugged me a little, the dialogue is so real. The director did a masterful job pulling the screenplay, performances and the perspective of "Room" against the much larger world Brie and Jacob are denied for so long. I'm so glad at least 3 of the 8 Best Pic nominees are worthy.

Not sure how to rate this one. It's the opposite of my go-to example of Wolverwine--a terrible movie that I genuinely loved. This movie was really well made, but I wanted to stop watching it very soon into the film because of the disturbing subject matter. I've never seen a movie like this. Spotlight is disturbing on a less personal level, even though it happened in real life. Of course, this could have easily happened and similar stories have happened.I did have a few problems with the movie--mostly the pacing and the structure. It felt like the movie could have ended multiple times--which I guess might have been intentional, but the real ending was powerful and moving.The film certainly tries to inspire and have meaning, but for me it's just too overwhelming in how disturbing it is.

I will admit that I was not very enthusiastic about seeing this film; I was worried that the story was gimmicky and sensationalistic. However, I'm happy to admit that I was wrong. The subject matter was handled very delicately and skilfully. The acting was exceptionally good. The pacing and dialogue were also very good. It's worth noting that the author of the original novel is also credited with writing/ adapting the screenplay, something that doesn't happen all too often. I can sincerely recommend this film to most viewers.

How many times in your life have you been forced to finish a bad movie, book, or story, all the while just wishing it would end? Rarely is that longing as desperate in our reality as it is for the characters in Room. When Jack screams at his Ma, "I want a different story!", you know there's more to it than just a hunger for a different bedtime yarn. Her response, "No! This is the story you get!", punctuates their situation, and ultimately our own desires, with such force it nearly knocked me out. Room, a powerhouse of horrifying drama and real-life suspense, breaks out from its confining premise with enough gentle moments of love to make it one of the year's best.If you can't tell, I'm being careful with the details of the plot. However, know that it's a setup that's about as bleak as one can imagine. Director Abrahamson (maker of the criminally underrated Frank) creates an atmosphere of intensely palpable desperation in his small sets. In lesser hands, Room could've been either an oppressively gloomy downer or dishonestly optimistic hack-job. Instead, it's both strikingly candid and beautifully grace-filledThis compassion for its subjects is thanks in no small part to the much-deserved-Oscar-nominated Larson, and young actor Tremblay. His character, in particular, presents such a powerful look at childish na�vet�, he gives us one of the most amazing examples childhood trauma and perseverance I've ever seen. That theme (determination through suffering) creates an experience that harbors as much exhilaration as it does tears. Piercing and gut-wrenching, Room is a film you may want to escape, but will be glad you endured.

At this point, I believe Room is the best film of 2015. It's emotionally jarring, and anxiety ridden. Jacob Tremblay gives arguably the greatest performance from a child actor that I have ever witnessed. This kid deserves his accolades, and truly should have been nominated for an Oscar. His performance was so mind boggling honest, it left me in awe.
Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give phenomenal performances and the story is brilliant.

Powerfull and emotional are just a few of the adjectives out there that are able to describe this very humane and heart wrenching story, and just as well it has many things to commend, from the acting to the editing, from the directing to the cinematography, all excelent aspects of a movie that doesnt pretend and doesnt go too far and that exactly is probably its most beautiful aspect. Its confidence, its belief in itself for what it is.
Truly phenomenal and uplifting to the human spirit!
Definitivamente lo mejor de este drama son las actuaciones de Brie Larson y Jacob Tremblay. La pel�cula trata mucho m�s sobre relaciones humanas que el mismo hecho de "La Habitaci�n".
A unique film in that it starts off very suspenseful, and ends very quietly... but in a good way. Jacob Tremblay does an amazing job, and Brie Larson delivers a strong performance as well.
Beautifully done. Best movie I've seen for a very long time.
Excellent movie. This is a moving contemplation on the relationship between mother and son. If you ever want to visualize Plato's question of living in a cave, this will answer it.

"Room"is a beautiful movie. It does not rely on special effects, guns, sex, action scenes or anything like that. Instead the movie mainly relies on the love of a mother for her son and her ability to go through almost anything just to keep her son alive and well. The acting is brilliant, especially Brie Larson and Jacob Trembley (this boy is definitely going places!). It is a bittersweet movie, hard to watch at times, but a great piece of modern cinema. 4/5 stars
Outstanding performances solidify Room as one of the best movies of the year.

Room is an interesting film and a very innocent take on a horrendous situation. Though not told only from the perspective of the child, Jack is the center of Room. He is how we experience and learn about the world that is Room. Though I'm not gaga over the film I did enjoy what was presented and how it was presented. It is both dark and horrifying while also containing hope and humour. Considering the subject matter involved... this is a welcomed choice by all those involved.

I read the book this summer and really enjoyed it, I was curious how they would bring it to the big screen because it seemed a little impossible. But somehow they pulled it off and made one of the beast movies of the year! It was great to see how the story unfold and how exciting, heartbreaking and harrowing it was told. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are fantastic and have great chemistry together. Also a shout out to Joan Allen doing great job as Brie Larson's Grandma. It can be really sad but could have been really depressing where it is almost unwatchable, but there is so much hope and that is where it really shines!
Hard to imagine how this book adaptation could have been better written, directed or acted. The movie goes back and forward from dark to light, from gut-wrenching to cute. Worthwhile experience.
I have no clue why this movie is such a big deal.

I've just seen the best film of 2015 and with so many enjoyable films made this last year, that's saying something. I won't go into detail. The less you know in advance of seeing this, the better off you'll be. Stunning.
A powerful and moving piece of filmmaking, Room is beautiful and distressing at the same time, with very strong, real performances and an excellent script. A profoundly affecting film.
Emotionally powerful. And honest. Great performances from the cast, specially Jacob.
Rarely does a script so elegantly express its characters. Larson and Tremblay are outstanding. Might be the best movie of the year.
Wow just wow. Emotionally heart wrenching. Fantastic acting. My best guess is Brie Larson will win the Oscar!
Wow just wow. Emotionally heart wrenching. Fantastic acting. My best guess is Brie Larson will win the Oscar!
Unique and gripping film. Thought the first half was more powerful than the second, though.

I can't remember the last time I sincerely cried in a movie. Room is a truly emotional juggernaut that deserves every accolade headed its way. Blessed with a cathartic soundtrack, confident cinematography, sure handed direction and unforgettably genuine performances from its two leads, this indie gem takes a simple, self-contained premise and turns it into a picturesque story as epic as life itself. The world is scary, strange, and incredibly beautiful when seen through 5-year old eyes.
Jacob Tremblay and Brie Larson drive this movie. Their performances slam you in to an emotional tornado that will not soon to be forgotten.

Hard hitting drama with incredibly touching performances, something quite rare this day and age. A real master stroke was to focus on the awakening of a boy as he senses and suffers existence; it makes you feel part of his progression and realizations, as he initially enters the world with his mind prone to fantasy and un aware of inhumanity.
An excellent adaptation of an excellent novel.

Very well done film. Larson as superb but this kid Tremblay was outstanding. Keep an eye on his career; he has the making of another DiCaprio. The direction was also deft and skillful. Always engaging and unusual, The Room lets us see the mundane as the miracle it is.

Great story..amazing acting by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay...their transition from "Room" to real world tugs at your heart....You want to hope for a happy ending for them....Recommend the movie..and read the book!!
tezak i jednostavan film!
This is one of the best films I've seen in a long time. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are absolutely incredible in this extremely powerful and moving film.

Made for Lifetime TV, YES. Oscar Nominee, NO!!!!!!!! Poorly made film with a shaky camera half the time. How the heck did this get an Oscar NOD????????
Does absolute justice to one of my favourite books. Watch it!

ROOM Review - Jack FitzpatrickSimply put, "Room" is an emotional film. And it seems as though half the time you do not even know what you're feeling. Seamlessly the film manages to portray happiness in a tragic way, depressingly dark situations yet also present some optimism and make you feel genuinely scared and/or worried about its fictional characters. Room is emotional in a very real sense; it's not just another movie where a romance falls apart, or where a loved one gets a terminal illness and it doesn't tug on your heart strings with cheap bullshit. Room doesn't try to trick you into feeling things, its realistic tone and grim story is enough. Not to make light of the cinematography, music or any of anything else which made the film, these are all good too, however we are really in this one for the writing and acting; the story and characters. The film follows its protagonists as they live their day to day lives trapped inside a small dirty room with no way out. Locked in by a nameless man that they call 'Old Nick,' (Who by the way totally looks like Will Ferrell's cousin or something...) The characters are a mother and son 'Jack,' 'Ma' has been inside this room for seven years and her son has never experienced anything beyond the room in his life. For around half of the movie we stay in the room with these characters, we as an audience never leave the room until the characters do. Personally I was beginning to feel the claustrophobia myself, the movie makes you feel as trapped as the characters are. The room feels hopeless as it does small and the atmosphere is actually quite haunting. Now though, that Jack is five years old, Ma believes that it's now time and that he is finally old enough to help her make their escape. Through a series of events, the two do make it out of the room, however we are still only about half way through the film as we follow their lives after leaving 'room.' The films point of no return; leaving 'room' is both scary and cheerful for both us and the characters in the film. The juxtaposition of being stuck in the room and the freedoms of such an open and unknown world is mind blowing. Yet, before they leave and it is uncertain whether they will succeed or not, you almost don't want them to try. Jack pleads his mother to wait till he is six years old and this is a terrifying theme throughout the film; Comfort and security over freedom. Jack's life and world may have been horrible, however the thought of leaving was frightening and almost made no sense to Jack. The movie manages to portray a horrible situation without feeling like a cheap horror movie, this is to be taken seriously and manages to portray despicable acts and conditions of the characters, without reverting to gross out moments or cartoonish dark villains. The villain of the film, is definitely disgusting and hateable, but ultimately is not the point of the film. The maturity of the film dealing with a sickening character and subject is appreciated. Another running theme of this film was the experience - or really inexperience of five-year-old Jack. He'd never known anything beyond this one room his entire life, basically; 'room' was his world. And this is such an interesting concept to me. Jack's concepts of fiction and reality blur and at such an age he is vulnerable to information. It's important to learn the truth however almost incomprehensible due to his extremely limited knowledge. Possibly my favourite shot of the film, has Jack creating shadows with his hands in the partial sunlight that comes through via sunlight. This shot has obvious relation to 'The Allegory of the Cave' philosophical theory. Put simply, if a caveman never leaves his cave, and all he ever sees are shadows, this is what he believes in, this becomes his reality. And the same goes for the child in the film. 'Room' is all he knows, and beyond stories he's told or what he sees on their television, Jack's sense of reality is inaccurate. He knows about animals such as dogs and cats, he knows about grass and trees and he knows about general bits of information, however due to his isolation he cannot separate reality from fiction and therefore will not know which things are real and which are not. A dragon for example is as real or fake as a dog in his mind. The themes throughout the film and the emotion that these themes bring are all portrayed through the actors; who all did a fine job, but the performance that really stood out was child actor Jacob Tremblay as Jack. Children are often not the best actors, they're still young; still learning, but this kid is ahead of his time, ahead of his age really. For such a thematically complex film as well as a mature and grim one, Tremblay did an amazing job making me believe in his character, as well as his collaboration with Brie Larson as mother and son, their relationship is strong and convincing. This would also be thanks to upcoming director Lenny Abrahamson whom I've never seen any works by, however this seems to be an early work of a promising career. (He also directed "Frank," and "What Richard Did."The film gave me chills when it needed to in moments of pure intensity the beautiful moments were made that much nicer in comparison to the dreary and depressing ones. It even gave me a new perspective on the world and the way we might look at it. What if we are all experiencing some version of Jack and Ma's 'room?' But, this is just a movie review, I don't want to get too philosophical. "Room" is saddening yet uplifting. It may be hard to watch for some yet I'd think also hard to stop watching, and overall the film has the ability to change ones' perspective. "Room" is shocking, yet beautiful and most of all unforgettable. This is Drama at its' best. 10/10

This movie brought me to tears. Not only are Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay absolutely outstanding, but the story is played out so well. I have never raved about a movie this much. This is a must-see. It will inspire you and you can practically feel the passion seeping out of the movie. I am so impressed with this movie. I cannot stop telling others. GO SEE IT!

I remember seeing a trailer for "Room" months back in 2015 and being almost entirely mystified; it looked like a strange, almost ethereal mix of drama and science-fiction that even the trailer couldn't adequately communicate. Not until seeing it, I realized that this is a film that isn't easy to summarize in a brief two minute trailer, and I'll undoubtedly struggle to illustrate the film's genius with its review. This is the kind of film one needs to experience and feel; a film where words often feel either exaggerating or shortchanging in attempting to illustrate the film's emotional power and exceptional narrative.Simply put, "Room" is the emotional moviegoing experience of the season. A deeply moving film that combines the aforementioned genres of drama and science-fiction, "Room" is the kind of film that hits you with its most powerful shot after you walk out of the theater or turn off the TV. It lingers in your mind and the characters, their motivations, their conversations, their struggles, and their thoughts don't escape you, unlike most dramas, where character names are probably not even remembered by most following the end credits.The film opens with a young mother named Joy (Brie Larson) and her small child named Jack (Jacob Tremblay), who live their life in an enclosed garden shed of about one-hundred square feet and their only available sunlight is a skylight. They eat, sleep, bathe, and cook in there, and for Jack, it's the only life he has come to know. At first, their routine actions and close relationship lead one to believe that they've chosen this life in order to free themselves from the constraints of society. However, we see the horror of their reality soon enough. Seven years ago, Joy was tricked and kidnapped by a man known as "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers), who raped her and had her give birth to Jack. Since then, she has lived inside this closed space; it isn't until their escape-plan is successful that Joy goes back to her mother and father and Jack finally experiences the outside world. Previously, Jack believed, largely in part of his mother, who tried to make their life seem a lot less hellish, that outside of the four walls of "room," as they referred to it, was outer space. The people on TV were just flat, and nothing else besides them and Old Nick existed. Upon finally escaping and trying to return to a life that seems brand new to them, Joy struggles to get Jack to assimilate to the world. His entire life was predicated upon just him and his "Ma," as he was largely kept hidden in the closet whenever Old Nick would come pay them a visit. Now, he must be socialized into the world at age five, and learn that there is not only a larger life, but a larger world outside of "room." His mother, on the other hand, must grapple with her demons that have haunted her since she was captured.If you look at "Room" from the perspective of Joy, you find a drama about being re-socialized into the world after living your entire life in captivity. It's a familiar story, but one that is truly sad and potent, and Brie Larson brings such life and emotion to the role for a woman so young (her precocious acting reminds me quite a bit of Jennifer Lawrence). However, if you look at the film through Jack's perspective, you see a film that plays with the realm of science-fiction. While nothing about "Room" deals with supernatural or "the unknown" in a grandiose sense, we do have a character who has never experienced life first-hand and sees everything around him not only as foreign but, for lack of a better term, alien. This results in a film that's very lucid and ethereal, largely in part because of Lenny Abrahamson's (who directed 2014's "Frank," a strong film dealing with mental illness) unique direction and cinematographer Danny Cohen's dreamlike grasp on reality. These beautiful and immersive aesthetic choices make the world and everything we take for granted and overlook on a daily basis look as if it's an unearthly object, with extreme close-ups and high-contrast depictions employed by Abrahamson. "Room" is a film largely bent on repetition; everything from Joy and Jack's daily actions in "room," Jack's attempts to socialize with other adults, Joy's attempt to come to terms with returning to her old life, and more are all showcased as recurring events in the film. This slowburn narrative tactic allows character motivations and interest to rise and boil accordingly, creating a film that turns impacting and even emotional when bigger, more elaborate events occur (the truck scene may be one of the best sequences I've seen in film last year). With all that and more considered, "Room" is a wonderful treat of a film; one that will hit everyone differently in a sense that it's not a matter of if it will resonate with you but how it will eventually manage to do so.
Awesome movie! I think this one might just steal the oscar!!

Beautiful story telling. Both this film and The Revenant are about resilience and the power of the human spirit to overcome, but the way that theme is portrayed here is a polar opposite of how it is dealt with in The Revenant. Brie Larson gives a performance that encompasses the intensity of her character's trauma, but does so with admirable subtlety rather than scenery chewing grand moments and demonstrates remarkable dignity and a sad sort of maturity that seems to be ingrained in the character due to the terrible events she lived with for seven years. The character and Larsen's performance reminded me very much of the kind of work we have seen from Mary Louise Parker. Jacob Trembley is brilliant as her five year old son. I do not know if the child was just that amazing an actor or if it involved excellent directorial and editing skills, but his performance is flawless. He carries the same sense of quiet about him that Larson does as his Mother, which demonstrates a detailed consistency that is spot on considering he only knew her and one place for the first five years of his life. The score is also perfectly subtle and reflects the feeling of the film brilliantly. The supporting cast of Joan Allen, William H. Macy, and Tom McCamus were also strong and their performances are consistent with the subdued intensity that characterizes the entire movie. This across the board consistency in all aspects of the film, from the colors, to the music, to the performances is what makes this such a standout work of movie making. It would have been easy to fall into soapy territory, but it never goes there. It is just pure storytelling with a director who very clearly had a vision of how he wanted this story told and carried out his vision down to even the smallest details. Excellent work.
terrifying griping incredibly difficult to watch with sprinkles of beauty and absolutely tremendous performances this is one of the most depressing movies ever

I was beginning to lose faith in the Academy's selection capability considering I've only really liked 2 of the Best Pic nominees so far, or consider them worthy. "Room" is a traditional Academy darling, and rightfully so. It's dramatic, emotional, suspenseful and a phenomenal film. The story is intense and heartbreaking (times 4 or 5). The acting performances of Brie Larson and young Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscar recognition. While I haven't seen all the performances nominated thus far, young Jacob Tremblay is jaw-dropping. I was excited to see Brie Larson, one of my favorites, finally show her stuff, and that she did. I hope she gets the win. However, Jacob blew me away. There were no words to describe how incredible his performance is for someone so young. Better than any adult actor I've seen this year. I'm serious. There is an incredible career in the making there. The screenplay, based on the novel of the same name, is beautiful. Aside from one scene that bugged me a little, the dialogue is so real. The director did a masterful job pulling the screenplay, performances and the perspective of "Room" against the much larger world Brie and Jacob are denied for so long. I'm so glad at least 3 of the 8 Best Pic nominees are worthy.

Hands down one of the best films I've seen in 2015. The chemistry between Larson and Tremblay is remarkable. The plot line will stay with you for days after you've seen it. Tremblay is fantastic and should have been nominated for an Academy Award.
A movie which explores questions of what it means to be a mother, what it means to give love, and what it means to receive it.

My fiancee cried the whole movie. Really hits you in the feels. Very good movie. Definitely had a greater affect on me being a parent. Acting was top notch. The little boy is adorable in the movie and in real life. Canadian actor! :D

Powerful & inspiring drama thanks to two brilliant lead performances & Lenny Abrahamson's direction that takes you into the horror of both living inside & out of such a situation. Larson is extraordinary as Joy, and wisely doesn't play her as a saint but a young woman doing the best she can in a hellish situation. She's paired wonderfully with Jacob Tremblay as her son, who convey's a wonderful mix of terror & wonder as a young boy experiencing the world for the first time. Honestly, you want to talk about an Oscar snub, Tremblay should be on that list. Behind the camera, Abrahamson does a superb job putting you into Joy & Jack's world, both inside the room and then later when they escape, especially by focusing on the perspective of Jack (simple things like the sky & trees never looked so strange & wondrous). The filmmakers also don't shy away from hard questions, including decisions Joy makes, which may seem cruel but do make some points. Overall, a truly inspiring film of survival and one of the best of the 2015.
You're going to love it.....What?....The world. - Ma and Jack
wonderful, touching, deeply moving, hopeful about the human spirit and capacity to recover from trauma

Golden Globes (and surely Oscar) winner Brie Larson gives a career-making performance in a movie that I will never, ever, forget. I can't remember the last time a film literally took my breath away. I couldn't even talk about this movie for about a half hour after it ended.Newcomer Jacob Tremblay is also fantastic in a performance worthy of a grizzled, seasoned veteran. Add in some solid supporting work from William H. Macy and Joan Allen, pitch-perfect direction from Lenny Abrahamson and a perfectly written screenplay, and you have the makings of the best film of 2015. Given the subject matter, Room manages to do the near-impossible: create an uplifting movie going experience without in any way minimizing the horror that is the basis for the plot. A tour de force.

Not sure how to rate this one. It's the opposite of my go-to example of Wolverwine--a terrible movie that I genuinely loved. Absolutely riveting in a very gentle, non-sensationalist way. Jacob Tremblay, who plays Jack, is only 10 years old and is absolutely brilliant in his role in a beautiful natural performance. Brie Larson (21 Jump Street) is also perfect as Jack's mother. The minimal soundtrack means that we are immersed in the story without distraction and Lenny Abrahamson, the director, has done an excellent job in conveying the claustrophobic nature of Room and the fear of freedom within the short time of a movie making us feel the emotions of the characters. ROOM is a profound exploration of the challenges of parenting, the relationship between mother and child, social expectations that undermine parents, the formation and modification of world view, acceptance, freedom - so much to think about. Don't miss this harrowing, completely believable, rewarding movie.

Hidden in this moving, dark story is a message of hope. A must see. One of my favorite movies of last year!

Room is a touchy story about Jack and his mother that was kept isolated in a "Room" by a man who kidnapped her, raped her and got her pregnant and is using her as sexual slave for more than seven years. While Jack now five years old, spent the whole life in that "Room", not knowing that there is a life outside the "Room".I started to watch every movie nominated for Best Picture, and Room is the second one after Spotlight. I had a feeling that there weren't a lot of great movies this year, but I'm happy to say that I was wrong.Room is another pure drama that will be stuck in my head for a long time. A masterpiece story by novelist Emma Donoghue directed by Lenny Abrahamson in perfection. Very touching, with great characters and great acting job.Jacob Tremblay is so young, I don't know if this kind of story would be a good idea for someone of his age, I mean psychologically. However, he was great and one of the things that I enjoyed most about the film. It felt like reality show. I feel sorry that he wasn't nominated for Oscar.One of the part that I liked the most was when Jack narrates his feeling inside and outside the "Room". I always enjoy the narration in movies.Story, dialogs, acting, directing and narration is great. A worth watching movie without a doubt. Different story, very well made.

Harrowing, yet beautiful. Sad, yet uplifting. Presents a horror of life, yet life affirming. This movie is a treasure and at the heart of it is a wonderful story about a mother and son. I cried, I laughed, I was on the edge of my seat. This movie needs to be seen by as many people as possible.

This is a special film that not a lot of people will be interested to see like myself before, but should see at least once. Lead by two phenomenal performances by Brie Larson and newcomer Jacob Tremblay, 'Room' offers a unique perspective on an all too often done travesty of abduction. The first hour is masterful done with some powerful moments while the second hour is still great and interesting when certain moments are slightly less outstanding in comparison.

4/4 stars. A spine-chilling first hour followed by a merely slightly-above-average second hour. The only change to make the film perfect would have been scenes from the eventual trial, which was instead mentioned in only two fleeting references.

Director Lenny Abrahamson once again proves himself with a incredibly emotional film, led by a wonderful performance from Brie Larson. The cinematography in particular has been undeservedly overlooked at this year's academy awards. It perfectly captures the contrast between the open-spaced universe of "Room" through young Jack's perspective, the only thing real to him for five years and the claustrophobic undiscovered world outside that he must become accustomed to.
Brie Larson and newcomer Jacob Tremblay feature powerful performances that builds up to a chemistry so extraordinary, it is almost heartbreaking to find that connection relatable.
Intelligent and moving. Best film of 2015.

If you haven't seen Room yet and you want to see a couple of spectacular performances backed by excellent writing you must go see it. Before seeing the movie I heard Brie Larson would probably win an academy award for it and after seeing it I was blown away. Room is an emotional roller coaster from start to finish. Even though half of the film is spent in one small room Larson and NINE year old Jacob Tremblay are not limited in the range they have as actors. Larson is about to explode into becoming a house hold name much like Jennifer Lawrence did with Winter's Bone. If you don't believe me watch Short Term Twelve, Larson's previous staring role. I believe it currently sits at a reasonable 99% approval rating. I am also excited to see where Tremblay goes as well.

A worthwhile watch, featuring two great central performances. Somehow manages to tackle some pretty heavy issues while still being fairly uplifting. A mother and her son, which looks like a girl, live in a room that has no windows, a locked door, and no light other than that coming through an overhead skylight. Jack (Jacob Tremblay), a bright five-year old boy with hair down to his shoulders wakes up every morning saying hello to his universe. He does not greet the sun, the grass, the trees outside, where he could run and laugh and play like a normal five-year old but only to the objects he knows for five years as being "the real world", his world: the lamp, the sink, the plant, the refrigerator. His only friend is a mouse that he feeds, thinking that the mouse also lives in that little world, the only one real for him. Sometimes a man comes over, during the night, and then Jack must sleep in the wardrobe, not to be seen. The relationship mother-son appears to be normal: they cook, dance, laugh, stretch out, read about Alice, mother tells the tale of Monte Cristo. The poverty that surrounds them is not painful. The real pain and anger I felt when Jack could not believe that outside "the room" exists a real world, with real people, and trees, grass, leaves, seasons, snow. Then the reality strikes: captivity. A child born in captivity, because of a madman, a rapist. A story of a child whose life started in a cage having as a talisman his mother love and her tooth, thinking that "his strong" is in his long hair. Real world proves to be scarier than "the room". A movie that should be seen, a story that must be known, a boy that deserves all the awards: Jacob Tremblay.

Wow! What an interesting idea for a film! Yes, this was adapted from a book, but STILL! This is such a good story! My eyes were glued to the screen from start to finish thanks not only to the enthralling story but to the mind-blowing performances of Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. I have never seen a film like this, and it works so well in every way. I agree with a comment I read that the less you know about this movie before you watch it, the better. Just know that it's great, and it doesn't disappoint. Fantastic film.
A credible survival tale with great performances by Larson and Tremblay.
Room is a thing of haunting beauty. Masterfully directed by Lenny Abrahamson and what I can consider the two best performances of 2015.

My Grade: A (97%),...Both highly suspenseful and deeply emotional, ROOM is a unique and touching exploration of the boundless love between a mother and her child. After 5-year-old Jack (Jacob Tremblay) and his Ma (Brie Larson) escape from the enclosed surroundings that Jack has known his entire life, the boy makes a thrilling discovery: the outside world. As he experiences all the joy, excitement, and fear that this new adventure brings, he holds tight to the one thing that matters most of all--his special bond with his loving and devoted Ma.
Emotionally terrifying; Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay ae a cohesive and remarkable onscreen family

Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay do fantastic work in the lead roles (Tremblay especially is phenomenally good for a child actor and should get an award) and the story is harrowing and emotional, but the movie itself felt a little bit overly long. When it was good, it was great, but there were other parts I thought they could have cut and it would've been a stronger film. As it stands now before a second viewing, I would call this film great but not essential.
Deeply disturbing and yet moving. Another notch in my "I gotta see some Oscar bait" belt...
Excellent! Incredible work from Brie Larson & Jacob Tremblay especially, but also from Joan Allen. I can't recommend this movie highly enough.

"Room" is one of the most vivid movies that you will ever see. The concept is fascinating: A woman is inexplicably trapped in a room with her five-year-old son. That's all. As the story unfolds, we learn details of how long they have been there and where their food comes from; however, the mystery continues to be preserved as we are left to fill in the rest with our imaginations. There are so many things that I would love to say but I want everybody to be just as surprised and on the edge of your seat as I was. In fact, this film contains ten of the most intense minutes that you will ever see in any movie. I swear, there came a point where I had to remind myself to breath. The story is an endless series of emotional highs and lows that create a deep connection between the characters and the audience. These emotional moments are enhance by a powerful musical score by Stephen Rennicks. Its absence reinforces the hopelessness and isolation of being trapped in the room, but then the score soars when it needs to enhance the joyous and devastating moments. I find that the most poetic piece of the film stems from one of the darkest psychological implications: The mental well-being of this young boy is completely dependent upon his mother but, when everything turns, he suddenly needs to become her strength in a time of need. Again, I'm doing my best to avoid any spoilers so you will just have to see it for yourself. The acting is astounding. Brie Larson will take home an Oscar for the endless number of emotions that she vividly portrays throughout the film. Her character is simply known as "Ma," a constant reminder that she has been stripped of her identity and her entire world is her son. She doesn't need a cape to turn her character into a hero. Jacob Tremblay was equally amazing. It is rare that I believe that a child performance deserved an Oscar nomination but his acting is highly refined and brings out a lot of our emotions. He holds his own against Larson's Oscar-nominated performance and isn't merely along for the ride. The realism of this story is further enhanced by its supporting cast. Joan Allen has been out of vogue for awhile but she delivers her best performance in years. It took a lot to steal the spotlight from Larson and Tremblay, but she definitely had her moment. Also, the very presence of William H. Macy adds a brief but necessary complication to this story. There comes a point where you start dreading that the ending will spoil the entire story. Dreading that, no matter what the ending, it won't live up to the rest of the film. But Emma Donoghue creates the perfect conclusion that allows this story to come full circle. One of the best pieces of advice that I can give is that you should NOT watch the trailer! Just take my word for it and blindly walk into this film. "Room" will keep you intrigued, emotional, and on the edge of your seat from start until finish. More importantly, you will walk away from the film a changed person.

This is really rather special. The child that played Jack was utterly sensational. The filmed which is played through his eyes and tells the story of a captured woman and the child that she gives birth after being repeatedly raped by Old Nick. Brie Lawson and Joan Allen were also amazing. Its well told and the horrors lurk silently in the background

Director Lenny Abrahamson continues an interesting filmography with this engrossing thriller/drama featuring two incredible displays of acting. In some ways this is reminiscent of 'The Shawshank Redemption' but here we explore further into the damage and recovery after a metaphorical crawl through a river of filth.

At its heart, '#Room' is a movie about survival. Not against the elements but survival of one's mind against insanity when faced with overwhelming and insidious conditions. It's also a movie that proves that #BrieLarson deserves her Oscar nomination. Her co-star Jacob Tremblay, who plays her five year old son, also gives one of the most spellbinding and believable performances of the year. It never gets too heavy. Instead, it shifts between being uncomfortable to being heartwarming and loving. It doesn't end in the typical Hollywood crescendo. Instead, it gives much needed closure to the characters as well as the audience. It is well worth the 1 hour 23 minute runtime.

This is great. If you're looking for a tense, emotionally satisfying, character driven film, this is the one for you. I wasn't familiar with Brie Larson before I saw this, but she's a frigging brilliant actress. I wouldn't be surprised if she becomes the "next big thing" in the near future, because the power of this movie is almost totally dependent on her and her performance. It reminded me a little of 'Joy' actually (And it's just a weird coincidence that her character's name in 'Room' is Joy too) because the story is essentially about a mother who has to overcome seemingly impossible odds in order to save her own life. This is obviously a much darker story than 'Joy', but I was struck my the similarity in theme. Moving onto the kid, Jacob Tremblay, he's excellent too. Now, good child actors are a rarity to say the very least, but this one has the right chops. We see the world and events of the narrative through his eyes, and not once did his performance grate on me or make me wince, like most child actors do with such a huge role. He was pivotal to the success of the movie and it really works.I had a concern before seeing this that the entire film would be set in the one room that the characters are being kept prisoner in. Not that I didn't think the film could work if it was, but just because I feel the material would get a little overdrawn if that was the case. I'm happy to say though that the protagonists escape the dungeon halfway through the movie. I don't feel this is a spoiler because this was hinted at in the trailer. But the reason why this is such a positive aspect for me is because I'm interested in similar real life cases and how captives manage to reintegrate into the world after being out of it for so long. This film deals with that very well and it satisfied me. There were a few things that disappointed me, but I don't think they're detrimental to the film or particularly harm it in any way. Brie Larson's father had a small role and I wish they'd expanded on some of the issues he was having with the whole ordeal, but they just wrote him out rather suddenly. I also would have liked more closer with the antagonist, the man who captured Brie Larson in the first place. Other than that, I don't have a negative thing to say about this. It's the sort of film that will stay with you.

An engrossing story with equally captivating performances, this is one of the most compelling original films of 2015. It's all the more refreshing in a year full of reboots, sequels and continuations.

Once you get over some of the incredulous details the director seems to have glossed over (e.g. no one heard the two of them screaming at the top of their lungs from a shed in a suburban neighborhood? The kid was able to grow to be 5 without getting sick once?), you begin to see the world from the child's PoV and you begin to feel the way he does about the outside world, outside "the room". I dont see how the Oscar could be given to Brie Larson while Jacob Tremblay is passed over for best actor, and perhaps the youngest ever. The movie needs some editing from the halfway mark, but watch the movie for Jack.

Seeing this story through the eyes of a five year (played by should-be-Oscar-nominated Jacob Tremblay) serves this movie right as "Room" is hands down one of the best films of 2015. it's haunting, touching, never wracking, pure courage storytelling. It's psychologically complex, and veers more into the realm of realist filmmaking than any other film of its kind (that I've seen).

The performances are quite good and it's hard to deny the power of certain moments . . . however this story was begging for a more stylistically ambitious film than the one we got. As it stands, "Room" seems like something made for television.

An absolute fantastic film that before I even jump into it I recommend everyone give this one a watch. Room is about a young lady referred to as Ma (Brie Larson) who lives in a shed with her son Jack (Jacob Tremblay). Ma was kidnapped when she was 17 by Old Nick (Sean Bridgers) and has been kept captive in the Room. Old Nick comes by to have his way with her and leaves her supplies. This has been going on for seven years and Ma has had enough. Ma weaves a story to Jack that there's only the Room and everything else is fake. It sort of places her in a position to think that this is life and to save her son from the horrific events happening to them. I don't want to spoil anymore, but the acting here is top notch. Brie Larson shines as Ma and the breakout star here is young Jacob Tremblay. Both really get you to care early on about them and some moments truly do get tense. Its a great film about the relationship between a mother and her child and the lengths that said mother will go to to protect her own. Only small gripe is that later in the film and by the ending there are still a few questions that never get answered! I can't recommend this one enough regardless!

There are not many films you could say "I remember where I was the first time I saw that." Room is one of those films. Based on Emma Donoghue's novel of the same name, we see the harrowing existence of five-year-old Jack and his mother Joy as they are kept locked away in a garden shed. The eponymous room is both their prison and Jack's entire world. There is only heaven, which he sees through the skylight, the space within Room and the fictional world of TV. Their escape unveils the true wonders of the everyday world to Jack, as well as a difficult adjustment back to normality for Joy.The two central performances are fantastic. Raw, heartfelt and utterly engaging, Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay emote the pain, grief and frustrations of their journey to profound levels. They're two of the finest performances of the last twelve months, so don't be surprised if both walk away with Oscars. That's right, Tremblay is that good!Lenny Abrahamson treatment of Donoghue's script allows for a poignant slow-burner that never contrives to exploit. We're given a beautiful balance of pain and hope, anger and joy. A bleak tale of survival and discovery has never had so much warmth. An intimate and thoroughly rewarding film that will stay with you for a very long time. It deserves every award it's given.5 stars.

A very unique film coming as a Canadian and Irish co pro that really celebrates the connection of parent and child under very dire circumstances and their attempts to maintain hope for the chances of survival and recovery. The Room jumps right into Ma and Jack as they are entering their final days in a confined room where the are being held captive for unknown reasons by Old Jack, and do extremely well in showing them playing and trying to enstill the normal values and such while only receiving the most minimalist of care from their captors. A sort of fantasy story telling approach helps Ma keep Jack innocent despite everything going on around them until his fifth birthday when it comes time that she feels he can handle an escape attempt to help both of them come from underfoot and reunite with the outside world. Brie Larson and Jacob Trimbley are really note perfect in their roles as Ma and Jack, you really believe their connection and despair, and Jacob was really gradually discovering the outside world with his grandparents and gradually adjusting to everything around him almost like a newborn even though he is a 5 year old. A very deserving if unusual choice for the 2015 TIFF Audience Choice Award and I will be intrigued to see what hardware it picks up at the Oscars this year. Macy are really good too, considering they have gone through their own hell as much as Ma and Jacob they try to sew back what was torn from themthe world is big and small, always changing, scary but still goodany 'room' big or small is our own

The only redeeming quality for this film is the performances of the main actors. Both Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay present somewhat compelling depictions of a woman and child who are held for a long amount of time against their will. However, as their predicaments change, the movie begins to hit the clich� 'notes' of a film that wants to play with your emotions, but without any insight on the suffering of its characters. It's as if this film's downfall comes from the fact that it was written by the writer of the novel upon which it's based, Emma Donoghue; this film tries to fit so much drama into its second half, yet it still drags as it provides a shallow impression of the psyches of the characters in this tragic situation. The film's flaccid ending seems like a halfhearted attempt at some sort resolution and relies on the viewer to imagine the changed-state of the principal characters--as it's not shown in any detail.  I'm sorry to say that this movie was ultimately unoriginal (at moments it felt like Peter Jackson's similarly-themed "Lovely Bones"), poorly written (laughable moments in the script "Needle in a haystack" etc.), and boring (zzzzzzzzz). I feel as if this film would benefit immensely if it was shot/told in a similar fashion to that of the novel upon which it's based: from the viewpoint of the imprisoned child. This is attempted in form of narration spread at different points throughout the film, but the somewhat precocious reflections are brief and, at times, inaudible. While I have not read the novel, I would imagine that telling/shooting the film in a similar manner would add some much needed originality and insight.  I would have given this film 1.5 stars because of its compelling opening situation, but, much like the agonizingly clich� sex-offender glasses of the character who imprisons Larson and Tremblay, its derivative nature is really quite ghastly.

A splendid and masterfully paced meditation on intimacy.

While Room hits on poignant ideas dealing with how mothers relate to their children and how children develop their sense of perspective from their parents, it's also built on a fundamental desire to make the audience cry that results in an incessantly maudlin score and some treacly, writerly flourishes that undermine the simple power derived from the premise. As Jack views the world for the first time and gains an understanding of what exists around him, it's beautiful and heartbreaking and succeeds in delivering the emotion Abrahamson so desperately wants to communicate, but it's underlined and reworked and restated so many times that the film begins to lose what initially made it so effective. Tremblay and Larson are both excellent; it's a shame they weren't given the vehicle they deserved.

A brutally realistic look at a captive situation, and a meticulous examination of the psychological repercussions on the victims of those events.

If Bree Larson does not win the Best Actress Oscar, then they should stop issuing the award, for it will have become meaningless. This is a grueling movie but not in the way you would expect a film about a woman and her son being locked in a shed for years would be. Emotionally this film grabs you in its teeth and drags you around the room. Jason Tremblay and Bree Larson give a masters class on ripping an audiences heart out in this little film. One of the years best.

Room is a good film, filled with gut wrenching moments and powerful emotion. Larson and Tremblay are as fantastic as reported and failure to garner Oscar nominations would only make the Academy look dumber than it already is. However, call me cynical and bloodthirsty, but I got the feeling that Room played it a bit too safe and ended a little too lightly. Ma's suicide attempt was awful glossy, as was the interview, while other topics were barely addressed at all. I get that this is a tough topic and I'm at as much of a loss on how to address it as anyone but I wish that Abrahamson had cut a little deeper on this one. You get the feeling that there isn't anything wrong with Room as is but what it could have been might have really been something else. Regardless, the film is still moving, still powerful and still worth watching. Larson is a lock for a best actress nod in my mind.
Well worth the wait. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay were AMAZING.

What a moving and movie-the voice of the 5 year old protagonist appealed to my 19 year old daughter, my 77 year old dad, my 52 year old husband, as well as my 48 year old mind. The focus on perspective, familial love and redemption was not eclipsed by the underlying evil, but rather superimposed hope on the devastation we witnessed. The "room" itself was a character which interacted with the stars in a subtle way. We were speechless by the end of the movie and I was impressed with how well it followed the book.

Again, I've entered this movie without having seen the trailer or the synopsis in order to experience it better and, again, I was not dissapointed. The story follows a mother, Joy, and her son, Jack, who have been living in one small room for the past 5 years. The reason is unknown until about half hour into the movie, so I won't spoil it. Anyways, at one point they get out and Jack hasn't been out of that room, ever. So, this is his first time seeing the outside world and it's really beautiful seeing that, I have to admit. How he is ignorant of everything and discovering everything for the first time. Joy has to deal with a lot of media and her parents and it's all very over-the-top dramatic. That's about the only problem I had with this movie. The overly dramatic plot revolving around Joy. It's interesting at first, but it just keeps going and going and it gets to the point where you're just tired of her character, albeit her actress is amazing. And so is everyone, really. There weren't any bad actors, not even the kid! The direction is great and the first 40 minutes of the movie which are entirely set in the small room look outstanding! I was always fascinated by the movies that are set in small spaces and how the directors manage to make them look bigger and more interesting. The soundtrack is great. All in all, Room is a movie deffinetely worth seeing as it is very emotional, the story is intriguing and the acting is brilliant. Not my best movie of the year, but near the top!

A film I have found out through the power of YouTube and one where I most certainly agree with all the buzz surrounding the film because it was absolutely brilliant and is one of the best movies I have seen in 2015. This film shows the power that a simple story can bring to the viewer and is one that is told in such a heartbreaking and thought-provoking manner. Watching this film, I completely forgot at times that I was even watching a movie and I was completely captivated and effected by all the situations going on. The performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are truly incredible here and together have portrayed one of the best mother-son relationships I have ever seen in a long time in a movie. With Short Term 12 and this under Brie Larson's belt, I am going to look forward to everything she does in the future and I hope she gets a Oscar nomination for this performance because it was memorable and one of the best performances I have seen from an actress in 2015. Brie Larson did a fantastic job portraying a mother who cares deeply for her son and will do anything for him and when she started having mental problems toward the final hour of the film, I felt completely sad for her and her son. Jacob Tremblay as the son was fantastic as well and he gave one of the best performances I have seen from a child in a long time and I hope that he will be in many more great movies in the future. Being a kid raised in an enclosed environment, I completely understood him whenever he would feel a certain way towards life or towards his own mother and there were a lot of heartbreaking and touching moments with them together. The dialogue in the film was fantastic as well. The conversations that Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay had were completely engrossing and her telling him about the outside world was all the more memorable to watch and listen to. There were many times during the first half of the film where I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see how they would gain their freedom and I was left breathless when those scenes ended. Joan Allen as the grandma of Jacob Tremblay's Jack was really likable and she showed a great amount of emotion in the second half of the film and gave a better than average supporting performance. While William H. Macy was a great presence as the grandpa, I could have had more scenes with him dealing with these heartbreaking situations, but because everything else was so good, his limited amount of screen time only felt like a minor problem and didn't detract from the film. Being from a small time director, Lenny Abrahamson shows here that he can get nothing but the best out of these actors and the simple premise, and I look forward to what he does next after this. In the end, I really had no major issues with this film and this was a movie that I was completely floored by and one that I can't wait to see again when it comes out on Blu-ray.
Fantastic performance from Larson as expected, but it's pretty formless outside of that.

Very, very good movie. Solid acting, especially by the child at the center of the film but the real magic is in the script. First of all, a very interesting idea for a film, based on a situation like the 1991 Jaycee Dugard kidnapping, but the script goes beyond the true story, creating believable characters the viewer cares about. Many moving moments in this film.
This was a great movie.

The film Room is the story of a mother - played by Brie Larson - and her five-year old son who are forced to live in a tiny square room. The viewer has no idea why they are living in this space but as clues are revealed as the movie progresses.This movie is excellent and a must see - I can't say enough about it. The style choice can appeal to both the indie film buff and also the casual big blockbuster moviegoer. It does a great job of using every scene to advance the story forward and the screenplay is written in a way that is believable. In addition the dynamic of the way the mother and son interact is not over the top. Nor does it appear forced. In the first act, I was impressed with the mise-en-scene and the shallow space composition done entirely within a 10 foot by 10 foot room. In the second and third acts, the movie appears to go in particular direction, but then it surprises viewers. However, it is done in a way that is not unrealistic or cliche. This movie is easily a top five film of 2015. If someone says it is not, then they simply never saw the film or do not appreciate a drama that does not need fancy CGI in place of breathtaking shots, top notch cinematography, and flawless acting to go along with a well-written narrative. This film easily gets a 10 out of 10 rating.
