Room is a marvelously directed, fantastically crafted and powerfully acted feat of cinema. The story begins in the titular Room, aka a shed in the backyard of a kidnapper. The film is split into two distinctive parts, Act 1 taking place primarily in Room, the shed, and focuses on a bit of the day-to-day life of its inhabitants, mother and son Joy and Jack. Captured when she was 17, Joy has been locked in Room for seven years and had her captor's, Old Nick as he is called, son. Jack is now a rambunctious, excited five-year-old who has only known Room for his entire life. Joy has made it her mission to protect her son and keep him innocent to the horror of their reality for most of his young life, but now must make him understand in order to get him on her side to escape. Their escape is a success, but leads into the next part: adjusting to life outside. Jack follows his mother through their journey to become part of the free world. Brie Larson embodies every instinct and insecurity of Joy in her performance, conveying a young mother's fears and connection with her child as well as a young woman's fears of having to be responsible for everything in her small uncontrolled world. Larson is complimented by her costar, Jacob Tremblay, a remarkably talented young actor who truly owns the screen.

This is one movie that might stick with you for a while. This movie tells the tale of a young woman who is kidnapped as a teenager, held captive for seven years of her life, gives birth to her captor's son, raises the boy for the first five years of his life in a 10x10 garden shed, escapes, and that's when the real struggle begins.Brie Larson is great as the film's heroine and young newcomer, Jacob Tremblay, brilliantly portrays the film's narrator. The young child actor plays the heroine's son (Jack) well because he manages to exude innocence and resilience without appearing precocious. I like that. Joan Allen, William H. Macy, and Tom McCamus are great as Jack's grandmother, grandfather and step-grandfather respectively. This is a great follow-up to Lenny Abrahamson's 2014 film Frank.
Powerful performances by Larson and young Tremblay in a tautly-written and emotionally draining film.
Room is riveting. Newcomers Larson and Tremblay give two of the best performances of the year in this heart breaking film.

A painstakingly unpleasant experience for the majority, with a cathartic dose of relief to cap off a deeply meditative and well-crafted film. Did I like it? No. Is it good? Very. Brie Larson, as they all say, was captivating.

This is one of those movies that, despite how amazing the performances by the leads are and despite how beautifully filmed and directed it is, you never want to watch again because it's just rough material to sit through.
This movie was harrowing but very emotional. The child actor was fantastic. I don't know IF I could read the book.
I don't cry much. But when I do, I'm watching @RoomTheMovie

Brie Larson delivers an unbelievably human performance in what may be the most emotionally powerful film of 2015. The performance of young star Jacob Tremblay as Jack gives the movie an incredibly unique perspective.
Led by incredible work from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, Room makes for an unforgettably harrowing and undeniably rewarding experience.
An emotionally stirring and harrowing story of survival. Brie Larson ("Short Term 12") gives a raw and powerful performance. Young Jacob Tremblay is mesmerizing.

A very powerful film about a mother locked in Room for over 7 years with the child she bore from her captor. It isn't an easy film to watch at time but it has hope without tying things up to neatly for mass moviegoing consumption. Brie Larson, not a mother in real life, hits all the right notes and then some and new come Jacob Tremblay acting is better that most adults. Brie is a shoe in for an Oscar nom but so should Jacob. His performance is better than any other child actors who were nominated and prob shouldn't had been. ONe of the years best

It's a fine film to watch when you don't expect much or aren't going to be critical about story-line details. To me it came across as a low budget, first time directors, masterpiece...with an emphasis on low budget and first time director. The acting was superb but I was just so frustrated with the far-fetched scenarios and a slow, somewhat unfinished, 2nd half. I hear the book isn't any different.

At its heart Room is a psychological thriller showing the true essence of the mother-child relationship. Terrific acting by all notably Larson and Tremblay. both who are worthy of Oscar nominations. Definitely one of the top movies that I have seen this year. (12-23-15)

A contained character piece that reaches far beyond the walls that is the namesake of this film. I've always been a Brie Larson fan, but this movie really shows what kind of dynamic range that she has. Dark but hopeful, more charm than I expected.

Incredible masterpiece of a film. Brie Larson deserves the Golden Globe for Best Actress on this. So happy to see her finally getting recognition. Very emotional story that took a surprising turn midway.
Room captures the emotional intricacies of the mother (Larson) and son (Tremblay) relationship within the complexities of life in and out of their shared reality.
With breathtaking performances and a heartbreaking story, Room provides one of the the most unforgettable filmgoing experiences in recent memory.

Emotionally gripping and gut wrenching, Room portrays the beautiful innocence of a child's mind and fantasy, surrounded by devastation. You will go on an emotional, at times suffocating, rollercoaster. This is due to beautiful camerawork, direction and incredible performances by Jacob Tremblay en Brie Larson. The latter again proving why she is one of the greatest actresses of her generation.This is a film that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled. Easily one of the strongest films of 2015.

This is a really good movie. This was sort of a fictional portrayal of the real life circumstances surrounding the Ariel Castro kidnappings. The idea of spending your entire life in a room and not understanding life outside of you enclosure is as amazing a concept as it is disturbing. This is one of those sleeper films that nobody has heard of, over the noise of The Force Awakens, and The Hateful Eight. This is definitely better than The Hateful Eight and will stay with you longer than the Star Wars movie... which I enjoyed too.
Damn fine filmmaking - though it wasn't the thematic perfection I went in hoping it would be.
Best film of the 80+ I saw in 2015!

Give Brie Larson an Oscar! She is amazing in everything she's in from the United States of Tara to Short Term 12 and her performance in Room is incredible. I'd read the book about Elisabeth Fritzl but didn't realise Room was based on her harrowing story until after seeing the film. The boy who plays her son is a superstar, I loved how he partly narrated. A must see, it will break your heart, make you laugh and make you cry.

Room: One Skylight, Two Great Performances, and Four Walls make one great film. "Room" starts in the middle of a horrifying tale of abduction with little back story and little history. And that works wonder. It places us right in the middle of the claustrophobia of the two main characters, Joy and her son Jack. The first third of the film made me almost as uncomfortable as I was during the whole masterpiece film, "The Act of Killing." There are so many times when this film could have gone awry, sappy and melodramatic. In fact, the sappiest thing about the film was the music, being far too uplifting and loud for the themes in the movie. The framing of each shot in the first-third of the movie augments the feeling of being trapped. The shots are as beautiful as they are terrifying. The acting of the two main characters is spot on, especially the five-year-old boy Jake, played by Jacob Tremblay. Brie Larson plays the complicated role of Joy, the mother, who goes through untold agony. We aren't told what happens in detail; we see it on her face, in her body.There were so many times this film could have gone for cheap sentimentality; they could have gone for the easy reconciliation and happy ending, and it didn't. Put one in the win column for small, well writing, well directed and well acted cinema that doesn't involve stunts or explosions. Rating: Pay Full Price"Room" is excellent. While it didn't play for cheap emotion and the issues it addresses are horrifying, it could have used more detail regarding the aftermath of events for the mother. The son's issues were dealt with well if not completely. The framing of the shots? Fantastic! The music? Terrible. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscars nominations. ??Peace,?Tex Shelters

Beautifully acted, directed, and scored, 'Room' is 2015's best film by a mile. Larson and Tremblay are beyond deserving of best actress and actor awards, giving two of the best performances in memory.

Close to one of the best and intriguing movies out this year, Brie Larson definitely deserves her Oscar buzz, but the halfway shift within the movie, although necessary (and refreshingly so), felt somewhat abrupt.

Atypical in nearly every way, "Room" is headed by strong performances from Brie Larson and the young Jacob Tremblay, playing a mother and son entirely foreign to the world around them. It has no climax, no rising action or central moment, but the film effortlessly reaches the necessary depth to convey the psychological struggle at each character's heart.

Holy crap this movie is fantastic. Edge of my seat precariously positioned between screaming and crying the entire time. A very difficult subject handled brilliantly and an emotional roller coaster with perfect writing and acting from the cast. LOVED it.

I saw a little movie called #ROOM today... and I rarely use the word, but this one qualifies as a masterpiece and is the best film I've seen this year. Grabs you emotionally from the first frame and doesn't let go. I was particularly blown away by the performances... Brie Larson should get some hardware for the job she does but the actor who steals the show is 9 year old Jacob Tremblay. I honestly can't recall a more amazing performance from such a young actor.  If you're looking for something more adult to see over Christmas, see this one. Dark subject matter but it's not a dark film at all. My grade: A+
Jack's narrative was pleasantly perfect, and Brie Larson! Cmon.

There's one thing keeping me from giving this a full five star review, and I have to admit that it's a very petty reason.'Room' is pretty much a film of two halves, and somehow I liked the first half better than the 2nd.But both halves are equally rewarding in their own right. Held together by wonderful performances from Brie Larson and the young Jacob Tremblay.It manages to be gut wrenching and beautiful at the same time and that's not an easy thing to do. MUST SEE viewing.

The first disconnection I felt watching this film was, the age of Jack, was he 5 ? or 7 ? I would believed him more if he was 7.Secondly if he was in that room for all his life, then the script written for him was more for a senior kindergarden.I can't help looking back to Danny Lloyd ( The Shining ) who was very natural which I think how a 5 year old child should be.Good script and performance, I like the story.. but since I felt those disconnection early, it was like watching a movie that was supposed to be set in Toronto, but someone messed up and showed the Empire state building in the background.

Quasi-horror film may be the most powerful film of the year as it is basically told through the experience of a 5 year old. To reveal more would be wrong, just go see it and realize what it is to be human, what it is to marvel at a world that is suddenly, very suddenly real all at once, with all its sorrows, challenges and surprises.

Stellar Acting by Brie as well as the young boy Jacob Tremblay. Was captivated from start to finish
The acting is A1 but the storyline what mother would risk her child to the monster alone ? And why did the mother adjust so easily after 7 years in captivity otherwise a Brilliant film
A both surprising & working twist & turn.A remarkable Brie Larson's delivery.

Heartbreaking, believable and deeply moving, "Room" is a spellbinding film that sticks with you long after you've left the theater. Although the story it tells is not for the faint of heart or impatient moviegoers, it is beautifully told, powerfully acted and impressively directed. It is unlikely that you will find an actress as committed as Brie Larson or a child-actor as convincing as Jacob Tremblay this year. Both deliver breathtaking performances that seem real and utterly believable. Perhaps, the greatest compliment they can be given is that at times you almost forget that they're 'acting'. Director Lenny Abrahamson uses these actors beautifully to tell a story with a universal message of hope. A message so powerful that it makes you appreciate your own life.

Wow! Jacob Tremblay is an amazingly talented young actor; he is stark, honest and innocent performance is central to this heartbreaking, yet uplifing film. The connection between him and Larson IS the film's soul. Dealing with a difficult subject matter, but being shown it through the eyes of the young boy, totally works. Would definitely recommend this to all.
An emotional movie where I was just looking for a little bit more. The performances were good and all but I don't know why this movie didn't hit me the way it should've.

Room its' driven by its amazing performances led by Jacob Tremblay, Brie Larson that make it an excellent film. Packed with touching scenes wonderful dialogue creative environments that contribute to the already beautiful film. In the end; Room should be among everyone must watch films as its one of the best films of the year.

I just saw the movie "Room" which is highly acclaimed and rated in the 90's on Rotten Tomatoes for both pros and us regular folk. It is a difficult one to recommend because the subject matter is so repulsive and difficult and the way it its told is a slow unfolding. This is a film, not a movie.The movie geek in me liked it a lot...brought me to tears a couple of times (but then I am in a weepy state right now so maybe it was just me). The intermittent voiceover throughout is the little boy, trying to describe the world through his own eyes. I will only share this: It is the story of a young woman who was kidnapped off the street at 17 and then locked in a room by a sicko man for 7 years, where she also gave birth to a little boy who turns 5 as the movie opens. The title is where they lived "Room" which was his only world until they escaped and a world that he often misses as he's trying to figure out what is real and not real and where his comfort lies. The performances are grade A. I give it a 4.5 as a film but don't recommend it for those of you who are looking for lighter entertainment.

Some movies you watch. They may be touching, they may be entertaining, but sitting in the dark you are always aware that you are watching a movie that has been created to entertain you. Some movies sweep you along, caressing your empathy and tugging at your heart, enveloping you in the experience of the movie itself. So it is with Room, the new and exciting film that captures the wonder and joy of life's simplicities and celebrates the power of human resilience. With a unique voice from director Lenny Abrahamson, breathtaking, nuanced performances from Brie Larson and the young Jacob Tremblay and a rich visual world captured through the eyes of innocence, Room is not to be missed!
Room is one of the most well-acted, heart-warming, and realistic movies I've ever seen this year, and it's one of the year's best films!
A very powerful film that deals with the lasting effects and healing process of a traumatic experience. It can also be quite tense and the performances are outstanding. One of 2015's best.

Room is spectacular. Ok, well, half spectacular. The first half admittedly flies by but it's such an interesting premise helmed by two excellent performances from the get-go. It's a movie I'd give an A+ up until the 1:10 mark (or so) but afterwards it starts a steady decline of mundaneness. It could have really benefited from a stretched out first half with more thrills OR maybe Terrence Malick assisting the second to try to actually capture the wonder of the world. Instead it's just a bumpy finish to an otherwise incredible race.

the insidious wicked nature of confining a woman and child to a fucking windowless room for 5 years is so upsetting to me that I could not entertain the idea of being entertained by such a film. TRULY TRUBELING

Such a story is hard to pull off on film. What works in the novel can't work here because film is a more objectified experience (and the limited view of the narrator can't really limit the scope of your own experience and the access to information through other channels). I loved the movie, but I have some issues with it, the main issue being that the second half never lives up to the thrills of the first half. Don't get me wrong - I still enjoyed it and the actors did some great work (even though there were some false moments, such as Jack's inability to handle a phone: Really?! That bright and adaptive kid who was so curious about everything and spent so much time observing people couldn't really get the chance to see others speak on the phone in the long weeks he spent in his grandmother's house?!) but the second half had a bit of a dragging problem, as if it they didn't know where to go with that story for a while. But I was immersed in it, mostly due to the unassuming visual flair. And the performances: wow, these performance by Jacob Tremblay and Brie Larson were hypnotic! I especially loved the craziness in the room, especially Brie's moments of clarity when she had to convince Jack of going through with her plan. There was something manic about her character and this ambiguity felt real to me. And Jacob Tremblay - I know this is such an extreme pitfall of a role and he makes it look so easy and there are so many layers and details to this experience of a performance. Go watch them.
This is the saddest movie I have ever seen. #muchheartbreak

Could possibly be the most unsettling movie I watched in 2015. "Room" makes you feel all the right emotions at all the right moments, and even keeps its momentum after its major tone shift halfway through.

"Room" is an emotive, powerfully acted and modest piece that refrains from cheap sentimentalityExceptional performances as Jack (Jacob Tremblay) and Ma (Brie Larson) are the highlight here. You won't want to look away from them-not that director Lenny Abrahamson lets you. He never tries to distract you from the fact that there's two people on screen the whole time. He embraces it. It's a wise decision.Abrahamson displays an unnerving knack for extracting emotion. The thinness of the plot is an issue with the source material, and what could have been a hokey feel-good or a crime thriller is instead a tribute to love, life, and human strength that (almosts) steers free of being overly sentimental.The performances are delivered in expert hands that know just when to slow down and let them breathe, when to cut, when to jack up the intensity. We get familiar with closeups and extreme closeups, and it works. The minimalist soundtrack is gorgeously composed and holds our attention during the many diaglogue-free sequences. The same stands for set design and locations. They're inobstrusive and they complement the film's true strengths. The emotional complexity that stirs (or roars) in every scene. The flawless acting. The characters and relationships that are built with such care and attention to nuance that the film's few falters are easily forgivable.A chance for a thriller moment is fumbled in the scene when Jack and Old Nick are approached by the first stranger with his dog. Perhaps Abrahamson felt that a more amped up exchange would have been an easy gimmick, but there was definitely something lost in choosing not to dial up the intensity here. The moment called for it.Regardless, Abrahamson's intuition for storytelling is obvious and refreshing. I only ask that he trust himself more. The pacing is organic, the shots are thoughtfully structured, and he knows how to work within the confines of the story. The film connects. And it does that without the triter voiceovers from Jack and the spots of heavy-handed sappiness (especially in the haircut scene). The music supports the movie well, and so it reaches too-cheesy levels when the film does. We don't need to be cued so obviously as to what and when we're supposed to feel. If you've done the job well, and Abrahamson has, we'll get there on our own.

Based on the novel by Emma Donoghue tells the story of Ma and her 5 year old son Jack, who are living in the confines of 'Room'. To give away anymore would be giving away too much of the plot. If you've read the book you've obviously got an idea of what happens however, for those that are not aware of this film I beg you to go in with no preconceptions and for gods sake do not watch the trailer (unless you want the whole thing spoiled).What you get from Room is a very powerful and emotive film with excellent performances from Ma (Brie Larson) and Jack (played by Jacob Tremblay, a relative newcomer whose only previous release was voicing a Smurf). The supporting cast including Joan Allen and William H. Macy also put in good performances. However it's the mother and son which deserve the plaudits. Brie Larson, who up until now appears to have been in mostly supporting roles in films such as 21 Jump Street and Scott Pilgrim vs the World, however in Room she really displays her acting capabilities and from this performance she should be a contender for best actress when award season comes around. As you watch Room, the second half of the film feels like there isn't much happening however, this is a film about the experience and emotions of these two characters and how their confides mold their lives and the effects it has on them psychologically. There are moments when seemingly innocent scenarios dispense a sense of fear, paranoia and tension which are caused as a result of the predicament they find themselves in. There are also moments elation and unexpected humour. But it's that sense of paranoia and fear especially with regards to children which is a reflection of today's society and is depicted here so well which makes this film both true and sad in equal measure. Room can be tough and unpleasant viewing, I saw it as part of Odeon's Screen Unseen and I probably wouldn't have seen it otherwise but I've very glad that I did.

My mom always forced us to watch movies about motherhood. She did it at least once a week. It was ironic because she would sit there, gushing about how it was so true, that mother hood was such a blessing and the most wonderful thing a woman can do, and then right after she would be back to being her abusive self. My mom would hate this movie. Not that Joy is an abusive mom in anyway. Quite the opposite. She did everything right, but this movie is extremely real in it's portrayal of such an overwhelming situation. I think this is one of the most honest looks at motherhood I have ever seen. She gets annoyed. She gets tired. She has days when she just needs to be away from him for a little bit. She gets a bit scary at times. She feels inadequate. But she loves Jack. She wants to be everything he see's in her through his tiny 5 year old eyes. I think this is a near perfect movie. My only real nitpick is that I feel like it couldn't chose a POV. Did it want to be from Joy's POV or from Jack's. But it is a very small nitpick as the movie shows us everything we need to see and nothing more.

Based on the novel by Emma Donoghue, this film is a small story driven independent harrowing dramatic thriller. And like many of its kind, the film has to rely on a great screenplay, solid acting, and moving character development for it to get wide recognition. The film delivers on all of these aspects. Director Lenny Abrahamson (Frank) has adapted the best-selling novel with grace and grandeur. Here is a film so artistically unique and deviant, chock full of genuine emotion thanks to two outstanding performances, that isn't afraid to take risks and surprise at every turn. The entire idea of 'room,' the abstract concept of space, is ever-present in the production. In their bubble of room, Ma and Jack are restricted, as evident by Abrahamson's close angles and tight shots. The small space allows for high concept filmmaking, and when they get out of room, it only gets better, with a new color palette and experimental camera angles through Jack's eyes. The entire film is seen through the eyes of this child, and it's genius. The title of the film makes the film about the space in our lives and in our selves and our need to escape whatever walls or restrictions that others ? or we ourselves ? have imposed on us. So our experience really is reflected in this freakish story. The film is about the vast room we have at our disposal not the small room to which we might accept restriction. This couldn't be further from Lenny Abrahamson's last film Frank, a bizarre music-orientated comedy. Gone are the idiosyncrasies that made Frank wild and, for many including myself, compelling, instead we have a moving drama that earns its sentiment. The concept of a mother having raised her son in confinement then finally breaking free has many avenues to explore. Having not read Emma Donoghue's book, of whom also wrote the screenplay, I mostly expected a small scale -getting out of the eponymous room then reuniting and resolving itself there. Instead, the film goes further than I expected, getting Ma ? also known as Joy, which is becoming a familiar character's name this year ? and Jack back to her teenage home with her own mother. The story follows twenty-something Joy aka Ma (Brie Larson) and five year-old Jack (Jacob Tremblay), inside a garden shed. We are, of course, unaware that this is a garden shed, but the size is what's immediately noticeable. Small, dark, and dank, with a single skylight. Jack, the product of Ma's kidnapping despite her insistence of his immaculate conception, is oblivious to the space of the room, or lack thereof, and equally of the world outside it. Most nights, a man called "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers) visits the room to have sex with Ma. But Jack doesn't understand this custom, instead letting his imagination dream up a world of wonderment, all existing neatly in the boundaries of the room ? where a mouse joyfully nibbles on some scraps and where his imaginary dog Lucky can frolic. In Jack's mind, the only reality is inside the room, and everything on the other side of the wall is most certainly outer space. After one particularly traumatizing night, when Jack wanders out of his hiding spot to observe the sleeping adults and is frightened by both Nick and an instance of physical violence against Ma, the fatigued woman realizes that she must coach the young boy into aiding with an escape plan to finally rid them of the restrictive imprisonment of the room. Providing any more details would soften the impact of the film, and this is one that is meant to be felt ? even if it's a true kick in the gut. For the first half of the film, we as viewers are held prisoners right along with Ma and Jack. We see what a patient and wonderful mother she is as she strives to provide some semblance of hope for her son, though in a nearly hopeless situation. When Jack turns 5, Ma begins to explain the outside world to him, as she knows they must try to escape in order for her son to have any semblance of a normal life. During this time, we are in awe of this 10 x 10 environment and how it is every bit the nightmare we have imagined while reading the articles and seeing the reports on real life ordeals. The second half of the film is equally fascinating, as we watch young Jack and his sense of wonder and caution at discovering the real world. We also see the psychological trauma that Ma experiences after staying strong for so long. Assimilating into society brings different challenges for both Ma and Jack, plus those of her mother (Joan Allen), her father (William H Macy) and her mom's new beau (Tom McCamus). The film doesn't shy away from their reactions, though some are easier to stomach than others. The different approach is felt immediately as Abrahamson traps us with his two principle characters, Ma and Jack, in tight and sometimes oddly framed closeups. It's a somewhat clumsy execution to show the claustrophobia and intimacy Abrahamson wants to achieve as he uses Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay's faces as blank canvases, but the effect is thoroughly felt, and the film's following 30 minutes remain its best. The photography decides to take a step back, but it continues to catch that raw emotion. Then, in a way, it doesn't go far enough. But it's interesting to watch it play in its happy medium. It does rely on some key contrivances to get there, such as the kidnapper's wonky perception and ultimately not fighting hard enough when he could have, but that doesn't take away from the gripping escape sequence as the orchestra swells and squeezes tears from you whether you like it or not. The only criticism of the directorial style was the lapse in direction that the story was supposed to take towards the end of the film. The entire time the story was told through the eyes of Jack. However, towards the last part of the movie, there was a shift that included some of Ma's point of view. This slightly took away from the ways a five year old would try to explain certain behaviors or actions of adults. Also, for those who have read the book, don't expect the movie to include every aspect of it. Just like every other film based on books, graphic novels, comics, or even true events, only certain aspects can be adapted and some must be altered in order to try and make the best move possible. The performances are superb and so consistent with the storyline, there isn't any pretense that any of this was stage or acted. The relationships are well developed within the timeframe of the movie and are delightfully varied to reveal the breadth of human responses to such a tragedy. Brie Larson had not only shown potential but delivered the goods with 2013's Short Term 12. It's a similar environment here with devoted maternal instincts but this time it's pushed to the brink of her skills as an actress. She's drenched in this exasperation that speaks to years of exhaustion. In the tone of her primal performance, she paints a full rich portrait of Joy's whole life from her carefree teen years to her brutal capture by Old Nick when she was 17, to every little story and lesson she's told Jack. Joy's constantly revising the way she raises Jack and while there's bumps in the road, it's a complete picture of motherhood. She balances resilience and vulnerability, hope and dejection with a fine tooth comb. Most times she commands the screen and offers one of the year's best performances. It's a film about the harsh realities of growing up, operating for both of the main characters, and it's a very sensitive and emotionally potent portrayal. Speaking of which, Jacob Tremblay may be the frontrunner for most supporting actor awards as his performance is better then a lot of child actors. How they got a kid this young to pull off the necessary emotions that few adult can properly show off? I don't know, but this is defiantly his movie. Is perception on the world and the adults around him remind us why we were frightened by the rest of the world as children. When our parents aren't around, we might as well be on an alien planet, stepping around strange sounds and sights. This child made me realize how one can see the world differently at a different age. Joan Allen, as Joy's mother, is heartfelt and shows unconditional love in a wonderfully nuanced way, whereas William H. Macy, Joy's father, is regretfully underused but doing the 'in over his head' thing Macy does best. On the whole, 'Room' is an emotional journey through trauma and discovery with the help of a very strong storytelling and acting. Room fell short in some aspects, though they did not sufficiently diminish the overall experience of the film. It brings different concepts for those to learn from, such as the importance of family, experience, and empathy towards others. If you want to escape the confinements of recent big budget films, or want to experience something moving that you will not forget, go see Room. The film deserves a watch!

It takes a while to grasp the circumstance our lead characters face -- living as prisoners for seven years in a sealed storage shed, a young woman has a child who has never seen the outside. It's horrifying and warmly engaging all at once. And then, in a beautifully suspenseful sequence, it all changes, revealing an entirely new set of challenges. It is here where Larson shines, and is likely to clean up at awards time. Heart-breaking study of a weird sort of PTSD.

Human exploration of people captive in films is a very interesting subject that Hollywood and independent studios produce.Movies such as Shawshank Redemption (1994) The Green Mile (1999), Papillon (1973), Rescue Dawn (2006) Empire of The Sun (1987), Unbroken (2014) Misery (1990) and Buried (2010) represents a wide variety of sub plots that goes from: Jails, prisoners of war and actual abduction.In the film "Room" Director Lenny Abrahmson explore the life of Ma (Brie Larson) and his son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) who are confined in this small room, which contain a rudimentary kitchen, a bed, a toilet, a sink and a skylight. The film starts when Jack is turning 5 and her mom is doing her best effort to celebrate this landmark, by baking a cake. Throughout the film develops, the audience discover that they are locked in this room by a guy called Old Nick (Sean Bridges) who bring them supplies every night and also for sex with Ma. Ma was abducted about eight years ago in the film plot. Jack is living in a reality that is only portrayed in his personal window to the world, the television. Ironically the real window of the world for Ma is the skylight in this room, she can see the seasons and the time of the day, but for Jack is nothing. He don't know how the real world is and his sense of space is limited but the fact that Ma is the only person that he ever interacted. For Jack the room is a confined world but is a world of fantasies, sounds, smells and strange voices ( Old Nick paying a visit to Ma every night for sex)Ma tries to give Jack some education by making him read books like Alice and Wonderland, but Ma also wants to escape and give Jack the life that he deserve. The process won't be easy...The escape is a beautiful and poetic moment which is also the biggest revelation for Jack been free for the first time. The film Room is a very difficult film to watch, is a movie about the love of a mother for his child, the wounds of a person been abducted for years, the adaptation of a little boy to the real world, but also is a movie about justice and human and family values.Brie Larson is outstanding in this role as well Jacob Tremblay, the film, is really well edited and well directed who carefully crafted with the art direction team the perfect space to make the audience feel locked in that Room.One of the lack in this movie is the development of Ma's dad Robert Newsome (Willam H Macy) his character become important when a pivotal moment happen in the movie and later vanished from everyone's mind.

Which of the following situations would you find the most traumatic? (1) You are kidnapped, removed from everyone and everything you know and love, never knowing if you will ever be free again. (2) You are born into a captivity in which you know hardly anything about what most people take for granted as "the world" and then are suddenly thrust into that world with almost no understanding of what you're seeing, what to do or how to behave. Stop. Think about it. Either situation would be a horribly upsetting and disorienting to experience. We see both situations play out in the fictional drama "Room" (R, 1:58). Although the film is not based on any specific real-life story, it does have a strong basis in reality - in the cases that we occasionally see on the news or in a true-crime TV drama. A young woman is taken captive by a monstrous person who holds her for years against her will. In some cases, innocent children are born into such situations, knowing nothing but confinement, with only a mother's love to depend on. Joy Newsome (Brie Larson) was seventeen when a man who claimed that he needed help with a sick dog abducted Joy and imprisoned her in the garden shed in his back yard. The man (Sean Bridgers), whose name Joy didn't know (simply referring to him as "Old Nick") kept Joy as a sex slave, bringing her just enough food and other essentials to survive. He brought her supplies once a week, but visited her for sex every night. Eventually, Old Nick's ongoing rape of Joy produced a baby boy. Joy named him Jack. Jack only knows Joy as "Ma". He has never even seen Old Nick. At a set time every night, Joy sends Jack to sleep on the floor of the wardrobe in the corner of the room. Old Nick punches a code into the door's electronic lock. He enters. He does "his business" and leaves. Jack is now free to climb into bed with Ma.The days belong to Joy and Jack (Jacob Tremblay). He's now five years old. He has never had a haircut, never seen a doctor and never left Room. The wardrobe where he sleeps when Old Nick comes calling, Ma's bed, a toilet, bathtub, sink, toaster oven, small table and old television is all Jack has ever known. As far as he knows, the world he sees on TV is all made up and the small skylight in the roof of the shed is outer space. To Jack, there simply is nothing else but Room, the mysterious voice of Old Nick, and Ma. For her part, Joy does all she can for Jack. She "cooks" the meager rations that Old Nick brings and she breastfeeds Jack. She's his teacher, his playmate, his protector and, basically the only person who exists.As hard as Joy works to make a life for her and Jack in Room, their situation is starting to change, calling their long-term survival into question. Joy has tried to escape before, but it becomes clear to her that she has to try again. Maybe Jack is now old enough to help - if she can get him to understand her plan. It isn't a spoiler to reveal that Joy's escape plan works, because that is what the second half of this movie is about. Joy is reunited with her mother (Joan Allen) and father (William H. Macy), who are now divorced. Joy and Jack move in with her mother and her mother's boyfriend (Tom McCamus) who do their best to help Joy and Jack adjust to their newfound freedom, with all that means for each of them.These adjustments aren't be easy. Jack has to learn... everything that you and I take for granted about our world. Joy has to try to get past the emotional trauma of seven years of captivity and having raised a son in that environment. Then, of course, there are certain legal questions that a family lawyer is now there to handle... and the media circus that naturally accompanies such stories in real life. This film doesn't dwell on the legal or public aspects of this case, but those elements are there in the background, even while this dramatically changed family focuses on finding a way to forge fresh bonds and move forward in the most difficult of situations."Room" is as remarkable as the story it portrays. Basing the film on the 2010 novel by Emma Donoghue (who also wrote the screenplay) frees the plot to explore a wide variety of issues without being confined to the details of one specific real-life case. Telling the story through Jack's eyes (complete with a judicious use of well-written narration by the boy) helps us to understand the wide ranging implications of such an experience for Jack, his mother and his newfound family. Director Lenny Abrahamson takes full advantage of these story-telling opportunities with his use of camera angles and the markedly different tone in the movie's very different halves. Topping it all off are exceptionally affecting performances by all the main characters - especially Larson and Tremblay. Although the pacing of the film sometimes lags unnecessarily, there is no criticizing this film's emotional impact and the importance of the lessons that it teaches its audience. I have no room to give this film anything less than an "A".

With a story that feels ripped from the headlines, Room will punch you in the heart with characters who remind you of both the fragility and resilience of humankind.It's debatable whether or not Room follows a three-act structure. I'd say it does not. I'm a fan of the three-act structure, and generally a detractor of films that abandon it. This is one for which I make exception.Room is getting all sorts of praise for the acting, and deservedly so, but in my opinion, it is the screenplay that should be most acclaimed. This is a film that shows a lot, but doesn't tell much.Ultimately, Room somehow manages the task of making unrelatable characters relatable.
