A extremely well made and emotional film with great performances by everyone, especially Brie Larson. One of the year's best films.
An authentic and emotional drama from a child's point of view. One of the year's best!

Simple yet profound, small yet grande, "Room" is one of the most complex and thought-provoking films I have seen in a very long time. Maybe not complex to everyone, if you look at the imagery, camerawork, and script choices, there really is something incredible here. After being raised in a room for five years, with no outdoor contact, Jack and his Ma Joy escape and see daylight for the first in a long time. Told through the perspective of the child, he is seeing the world, people, objects, and nature, all for the first time. The emotional impact that has on the story is breathtaking. Brie Larson gives a gut-wrenching performance and I believed every single scene she was in. Starting from a confined room, you really begin to see what the world is truly like and how we take everything for granted that is in it. I loved "Room" from start to finish. Although I believe this is a brilliant film overall, I have to complain about the way they were able to escape. It felt a little too easy and then that tension was gone throughout the rest of the film in order to focus on the emotional heft, i.e. the family. In the end, "Room" has a very raw and true screenplay, incredible performances, inspiring visuals, and a story that is once in a generation, and we do not get many of those. I wish it did not have an easy way out in the opening act, but overall, I feel I can still give it a perfect score. See this film!

I enjoyed this film. It is very much a dramatic thriller that explores some dark morose subject matter. Yet the film's main character "Jack" reflects child like eyes and wonderment that gives the entire film, the bright light that only the purity of a child's soul can illuminate in the darkness. Also for fans of ?#?trueCrime? ?#?drama? ?#?thriller?
Beautiful, heart wrenching and tense. This child's view into a horrific ordeal and its aftermath is something special in a year that has been rather mediocre. A+
Not subtle or sophisticated enough for my taste, "Room" is nevertheless moving and well-acted.

I'm generally skeptical of child actors, but Jacob Tremblay...wow an incredible performance- subtle and refined. Brie Larson's acting is believable without seeming overdone. The movie critically examines the theme of freedom- what is it? at what cost? how does it change you? - ironically, through claustrophobic and rather myopic storytelling.
Beautiful story and wonderfully well made.

Room is one of the greatest movies I've ever seen. There. I said it. That's a big statement but it's true. The movie is heartbreaking but completely uplifting. My eyes were watery the entire time. It's hard to imagine Brie Larson and 9 year old Jacob Tremblay not getting Oscars for their performances. Larson is so convincing you forget she's acting. Tremblay gives one of the best child performances I've ever seen in a film. Unbelievable. SO UNBELIEVABLE!!!I could rave about this all day. Let's also not forget Joan Allen who's wonderful in a supporting role. The heartbreak of Room comes from the horror of being kidnapped for 7 years and the guilt Larson's character feels for her son being raised as a victim. Then the movie moves you by showing the world through Tremblay's eyes after he and his mother escape their abductor. It's so real. So powerful. This is the best movie of the year.

I'm honestly at a loss to describe why I liked this, so I'm just going to keep it simple. Brie Larson is outstanding as the kidnapped mother of young Jack (Jacob Tremblay, also really good), who has raised him to believe the entire world is the room where she's held captive, until she uses him as a means of escape, and then simply how they both react to being in the world -- her coping with changes since she's been gone, and him for the first time. I have a few issues with the story, mainly how we never learn much about the grandmother, her boyfriend, or the severely underutilized William H Macy as the grandfather. However, since it's mostly from Jack's viewpoint those would have been difficult to explore anyway. Definitely worth checking out for the performances alone.

When I saw Short Term 12, I told everyone to keep an eye out for Brie Larson. After watching ROOM, I will make sure people will know who Brie Larson is. Larson gives the performance of the year as a woman trapped in a windowless room for seven years with her five-year old son. The first act is harrowing and unsettling and you can feel the dread of the two. As good as Larson is, Jacob Tremblay who plays her son gives one of the best performances from a child actor I have seen in a long time. Both should be mentioned come awards season. The movie is about the love of a mother and child and the innocence of that child who has been hidden from the world his entire life. One of the best films of the year. Grade: A

STUCK HOME SYNDROME - My Review of ROOM (4 Stars)Don't let the bright wonderment of the poster fool you, ROOM is one of the most emotionally devastating films of the year, anchored by beyond stellar performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, a young Canadian actor whose focus and range rivals that of Tatum O'Neal in PAPER MOON. Prepare to be gutted. It's almost impossible to describe this film without spoilers, but I'll do just that. If you've read Emma Donoghue's novel, of which she adapted for the screen, then you already know the basic premise of a mother (Larson) raising her 5-year-old son, Jack (Tremblay) in a tiny room. Shielding him from the world for reasons that become clear upon viewing, he doesn't know that any type of life exists beyond his four walls. Think of this as a much more emotionally vibrant and more honest sister film to LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL, which also explored the lengths a parent will go to in order to protect their child. Much of the first half of this film is fraught with unbearable suspense, with the mother doing everything she can to resolve their situation. Danny King, whose work on LES MISERABLES did not make me a fan, employs a live camera and a lot of shallow focus to put the point of view squarely on the shoulders of our two protagonists. Yes, it's a claustrophobic experience, but to feel otherwise would be doing the subject matter a disservice. Director Lenny Abrahamson has made an intimate film about big ideas, and there's very smart economy in its storytelling. It's overlong by at least 20-30 minutes, however, and with such a generous running time of almost two hours, you would expect a little more to William H. Macy's lightly sketched in, barely there character. It's not that he's incapable, but he's given way too little to work with here. Not so of Joan Allen, who digs deep with limited screen time as well. Also tremendously effective in supporting roles are Sean Bridgers, who has a knack for keeping an audience on edge, Wendy Crewson as a journalist who prods just a little bit too much, and Amanda Brugel, as a woman who has to assert herself in order to cut through the muck. I could have done without the tin can-style of recording the voiceover, which certainly feels unsettling, but was truly difficult to comprehend at times. The score by Stephen Rennicks is certainly beautiful and heartfelt, but he could have dialed it back a hair with the final music cue. There was so much sap in it, I was tempted to call the film MUSHROOM! Far from it, this is a challenging experience, often seen through tears, and not an easy sit for any parent who worries about their child. Larson and Tremblay should be firmly in the mix come Awards season. Larson continually surprises me with her performances. Looking like Reese Witherspoon's sister, I keep expecting her to act goofy and self-conscious, yet her instincts are so vibrantly attuned to the material, she seems incapable of making a false move. Whether he has natural abilities or was heavily directed, Tremblay is a highly sympathetic actor whose ability to annoy, infuriate and warm an audience's heart, sometimes within the same scene, is something special to behold. ROOM is very dark, sad, and sometimes without a shred of hope, yet this tale of a Herculean bond between mother and son is well worth all the sobbing you'll likely find yourself doing afterwards.

"Room" | C+ | During the first half, Larson and Tremblay's smoldering chemistry is beyond Oscar-worthy. The atmosphere is breathtaking and the suspense is brilliant. Things slow the moment the kidnapping sex offender appears on screen. Then, sadly, the film's momentum comes to a screeching halt at the moment the villain reaches a stop sign (unfortunate irony!) and what should've been the most dramatic cinematic moment of the year, fizzles out. The movie falls off a cliff. The second half is chemistry-free with poorly written, cartoon character subplots unworthy of a bad Lifetime TV movie. I pray Larson & Tremblay receive the nominations they deserve, but the writer and director need a remedial course in "Choices Filmmakers Should Avoid At All Costs!"

This film has stayed with me a long time, Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are incredibly in character. Never did I see them as actors in their roles. The story is believable though difficult. Spoiler alert, it ends well, otherwise I couldn't recommend it.
A must-see for everybody. So so good!!!
Its not the Tommy Wiseau one.

Excellent performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay make Room's extremely interesting concept a heartfelt tale of mother-son love. That this concept is reduced to a mother-son love story is something I'm mixed about, but for sure Room is an enjoyable and touching movie. The young Jacob Tremblay carries the film on his teeny shoulders with surprising ease. This is a weirdly good performance from a child and I mean that in the best way possible. Tremblay's mature performance effectively conveys his character's ignorance to the world and how he experiences the world for the first time. Brie Larson is great as well as the mother who does her best to protect her son and properly raise him in their strange situation. Her character isn't explored explicitly, since the film is through Jack's eyes, but we understand her through the depth of Larson's performance where she unveils years of psychological torment through her eyes. She is also great in capturing the loving kindness of a mother, no matter how imperfect she may be. Together, Larson and Tremblay have believable and often beautiful chemistry as a small family who has lived in a shed with (pretty much) only each other for five years. Lenny Abrahamson's direction is effective at showing us the world through Jack's eyes. Through his camera, Room (what they refer to their shed as) feels like a home where nothing else needs to exist, and the outside world is often scary or dizzying. Off-kilter angles convey Jack's perspective very organically and the close-ups and handheld movements of the camera capture the emotion of the characters. Watching the film, I was excited to see where the film would take its concept and how it would choose to study its main characters. After all, the concept is so interesting. The film signaled to me the potential to explore themes of trauma or parenting through this unique scenario. I was let down a little by the end, when it seemed that the film wanted to settle for a sweet mother-son love story when I thought it would go somewhere deeper and more exciting. It seems to understand the psychology of the mother and son, but never quite examines it the way the film practically demands. It doesn't fail at being a sweet movie and emotional movie. For me, the emotional peak was in the middle, but nothing made me need tissues despite many having advised audiences to bring them. In presenting a touching story of a mother and son who were each other's strength in overcoming what they did, the movie mostly succeeds, and the two lead performances are unforgettable. I just hoped there would be a little more.

Genuinely one of the most moving films I've seen in recent memory. A film that proves that there are still original stories to be told. You absolutely have to go and see this at your first opportunity! It's heavy and harrowing and, ultimately, a deeply affecting emotional experience. Not a light "popcorn movie" night out. But so worth it.

Terrific performances highlight what is a wrenching and very emotional film. The filmmakers do a good job of having the film be almost entirely from the young boys point of view... and that technique makes the film even more suspenseful as we experience things along with him.

Not a dry eye in the crowd for the special preview. Jacob Tremblay's performance is amazing, as is Brie Larson's. It opens with mystery, builds the story, throws in drama, and melts your iciest heart along the way. This is original storytelling as it should be.
Great performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. Wonderful script by Emma Donoghue and direction by Lenny Abrahamson.

Led by the masterful work of Brie Larson and (newcomer) Jacob Tremblay, gut retching dialogue, and an emotionally raw story, Room is beautiful in every sense of the word. It is without a doubt a modern day masterpiece.

Room's wonderful performances and excellent direction are backed by a screenplay that's filled with subtlety, intelligence, and heart. Though Room has a few minor errors, such as a final act that feels like it could have benefitted from an additional scene or two of development, there are very few films that have had me as emotionally invested in a story as Room, making it one of the best movies of the year. And if that isn't enough, one sequence in the film had me on the edge of my seat more than any sequence in a film this year.
Damn man. Like In America meets Martha Marcy May Marlene meets Prisoners. Dope.
Such a powerful and beautiful movie. It is difficult to watch at times, but worth it. Excellent. I expect/hope this gets some Oscar nominations.
Suspenseful, gut-wrenching, emotionally rich. My favorite film of the year.
exceptional performances and effective direction elevate this film to a top 10 contender for the year.

Brie Larson is starting to make herself into one of the finest actors working right now and with Room it seems as if she's made perhaps her biggest statement, even more so than her outstanding work in Short Term 12. Larson her isn't so much in top form as she is at her most vulnerable, emotionally wracking, and jaw-droppingly good as she'll ever be, a performance that rocks the year so far for being one of the best acting performances we'll see all of 2015. It's the kind of role you lose yourself in, scene after scene of heartbreak and difficulty. Her role of Joy is one of the most emotionally demanding roles one could ask for and Larson delivers with astounding results. While her performance is part of what makes the film, the film itself doesn't suffer from relying on a single aspect, but is a richly emotional journey about a subject not always explored in film. Jacob Trembly is also particularly good as her son Jack, raised in the most unusual and disturbing of circumstances, a performance that was either made by the actor, the director, or the editor, it doesn't matter as it's incredibly convincing, the perfect balance to Larson's Ma/Joy that creates an unbreakable mother/son dynamic. The script, surprisingly written by the author who shows a surprising amount of screenwriting intelligence, has made a wholly convincing script grounded in reality and humanity along with a director with an eye for realism while remaining in the art of filmmaking. Room is a great film, maybe one of the best so far this year, a richly emotional film of sorrow and heart in the end. Someone may find it hard to watch, but it's also impossible to wrench your eyes away

Simultaneously one of the scariest, most moving, realistic, intriguing, and thought-provoking movies I've ever seen. No qualifiers, this isn't one of the best dramas I've ever seen, or one of the best movies from 2015, this is simply one of the best movies I've ever seen.
The book was super good! I am curious to see how they do the movie.

Lenny Abrahamson and Emma Donoghue certainly deserve applause for the tense direction and haunting, gut-punching script that gives Room its foundation. But the beautiful, heartbreaking performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay make Room unforgettable. They are absolutely marvelous together.
I hope the awards don't overlook Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, and Joan Allen. Simply fantastic.
Brilliant! Much, much better than the book!

A taut and tense first half leads to a much looser, weaker, at times infuriating 2nd --- including a "primetime TV' interviewer who posed the most stupid and insensitive questions that no network primetime TV show would ever ask -- and without any protest from the interviewee's party. Special mention for the young actor playing the son who is exceptional.

A young mother and her son are locked up in a room with no windows but only a skylight. We soon found out why they are there and they hatch a plan to escape. Part tense thriller and part PTSD the movie, the most intriguing aspect of this emotional film however is that it was told all through the child's point of view. This fresh approach manages to find the humanity and even the humour in the cruel and inhuman situation they found themselves in. A pair of great performances by Brie Larson and the very natural Jacob Tremblay is simply the icing on the cake.

Room is the wonderful and emotional tale of a young boy going into the outside world for the first time due to being held captive in a 'room' his entire life alongside his mother, joy, who will have to cope with the pressure. I tell you what, Lenny Abrahamson has absolutely done it again. Room is a masterpiece of character development, drama and suspense. You really care about everyone in this movie apart from the captor. It is truly great emotional dialogue and film work that moves you so much and changes your perspective on how our world would work to that of, essentially, an alien. It's not completely perfect per say...the first few scenes set up this child to be annoying and thank god that the opposite happened. Apart from that, pure rich dramatic cinema.
I definitely want to see this. The book was awesome.
I have actually read the book and I can't wait to see if the movie does it justice.

At the start of Room, a young woman and her five-year-old son are living in the titular edifice, a backyard shed. The woman (Brie Larson) has always told Jack (Jacob Tremblay) that "outer space" is all that exists outside Room; as far as Jack is concerned, this is the gospel truth and the universe consists of Room and Room alone.It is not giving anything away to note that Ma and Jack escape Room, as the movie is more about the ability of each to cope with the outside world. For Jack, every step and every breath outside is a wholly new experience. Ma, despite having lived for 17 years before coming to Room, encounters different obstacles - the world has moved on, and she doubts her own ability as a mother to Jack.I had been expecting a suspenseful drama-thriller about a daring escape, given the various synopses I'd read. (The movie is based on a novel by Emma Donoghue, which is itself loosely based on real events.) Much of the first half of the film, though, concentrates on life inside Room for Ma and Jack. Ma uses her strong will and infinite patience to convince Jack for five years that all is well and that what they have is a normal life, that what they see on television is not real, but everything from the single bed to the lidless toilet tank is definitely real. Ma sacrifices as much as she can to keep Jack happy and (relatively) safe, even to the point of giving herself over to her captor on a regular basis in exchange for food and other items for Jack and herself.To say that this first half moves slowly would be to understate things. We don't just get a slice of the life that the duo leads; we get the entire pie, and most of it just isn't all that exciting or intriguing. We do get to see a little into the characters of the characters, pardon the phrasing. We see that Jack doesn't like to not get his way or to have his worldview challenged. Then again, who does at age 5? We see that Ma is often calm but firm with her young charge. It's a small Room, after all; no need to go nuclear when there's really no point to it. In any event, much time is spent watching their everyday sheltered lives. Because the general plot involved their lives beyond Room, I began to grow impatient: Were they going to spend the entire movie in Room, only to escape in the final minutes? Why wouldn't anything happen? The fact that Ma and Jack would eventually escape left the first half of the movie perfectly devoid of suspense. Although still waters do often run deep, I didn't really feel like I was getting a lot out of watching a whole lot of nothing.Once they do escape, though, things pick up. The focus quickly shifts from a struggle for survival to a struggle to understand. Ma's parents, played by Joan Allen and William H. Macy, have different reactions to the return of their daughter and the arrival of their new (to them) grandson. In the five years since Ma's abduction, her parents have separated; her dad lives on the other side of the country now, and her mom lives with her friend Leo (Tom McCamus). With Ma's return, there's a lot of media hype, and lawyers, atop a potent array of stress factors. Escaping may have been the easy part.The acting is uniformly terrific. Larson's work is powerful, evocative, and heart-wrenching, and it's definitely award worthy. Allen and Macy also excel with perhaps the best work in their respective careers, and that's saying something. Young Tremblay is also very good - as is his character, a plucky, long-haired cherub who's more at home in Room than in the outside world (and with good reason).But the acting cannot overcome what's basically a very turgid script. Room is punchless at its core, and it would be a total waste if it weren't for the Herculean efforts of its talented cast. When there is no action, I look for meaning. When there is no meaning or action, I look for the exit. Room suffers from spending too much time contemplating things and not enough time doing them - or at least discussing them. Forget the action, I wouldn't have minded seeing more reaction. The first half of the movie could have been subtitled "A Series of Plodding Events." The second half goes a long way toward saving the first, thanks in part to additional characters and a fresh setting, but it's not enough to save the entire movie.

VIFF Review: One of the year's best that features brilliant performances from it's two leads who bring this harrowing tale to life. "Room" is an emotional ride that could easily find it's way at The Oscars in 2016 with acting nominations for both Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, best adapted screenplay, best original score, best director, and best picture! SEE IT!
Give this kid an Oscar.
The book was an excellent read. Hope the movie lives up to it.
